Text

PREFACE The ungentle laws and customs touched upon in this tale are historical , and the episodes which are used to illustrate them are also historical . It is not pretended that these laws and customs existed in [England]1-england in the sixth century ; no , it is only pretended that inasmuch as they existed in [the English]2-the english and other civilizations of far later times , it is safe to consider that it is no libel upon the sixth century to suppose [them]337-them to have been in practice in that day also . One is quite justified in inferring that whatever one of these laws or customs was lacking in that remote time , [its]338-its place was competently filled by a worse one . The question as to whether there is such a thing as divine right of [kings]339-kings is not settled in this book . It was found too difficult . That [the executive head of [a nation]341-a nation]340-the executive head of a nation should be [a person of lofty character and extraordinary ability]342-a person of lofty character and extraordinary ability , was manifest and indisputable ; that none but [the Deity]343-the deity could select that head unerringly , was also manifest and indisputable ; that [the Deity]343-the deity ought to make that selection , then , was likewise manifest and indisputable ; consequently , that [He]343-the deity does make it , as claimed , was an unavoidable deduction . [I]0-i mean , until [the author of this book]345-the author of this book encountered [the Pompadour]346-the pompadour , and [Lady Castlemaine]110-lady castlemaine , and [some other executive heads of that kind]347-some other executive heads of that kind ; these were found so difficult to work into the scheme , that it was judged better to take the other tack in this book ( which must be issued this fall ) , and then go into training and settle the question in another book . It is , of course , a thing which ought to be settled , and [I]0-i am not going to have anything particular to do next winter anyway . [MARK TWAIN]111-mark twain [HARTFORD]3-hartford , July 21 , 1889 [A CONNECTICUT YANKEE IN KING ARTHUR]348-a connecticut yankee in king arthur 'S COURT A WORD OF EXPLANATION It was in [Warwick Castle]4-warwick castle that [I]0-i came across [the curious stranger whom [I]0-i am going to talk about]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about . [He]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about attracted [me]0-i by three things : [his]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about candid simplicity , [his]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about marvelous familiarity with ancient armor , and the restfulness of [his]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about company -- for [he]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about did all the talking . [We]350-we fell together , as [modest people]351-modest people will , in the tail of the herd that was being shown through , and [he]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about at once began to say things which interested [me]0-i . As [he]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about talked along , softly , pleasantly , flowingly , [he]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about seemed to drift away imperceptibly out of [this world]352-this world and time , and into some remote era and [old forgotten country]353-old forgotten country ; and so [he]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about gradually wove such a spell about [me]0-i that [I]0-i seemed to move among the specters and shadows and dust and mold of a gray antiquity , holding speech with a relic of it ! Exactly as [I]0-i would speak of [[my]0-i nearest personal friends]354-my nearest personal friends or [enemies]355-enemies , or [[my]0-i most familiar neighbors]356-my most familiar neighbors , [he]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about spoke of [Sir Bedivere]112-sir bedivere , [Sir Bors de Ganis]113-sir bors de ganis , [Sir Launcelot]114-sir launcelot of [the Lake]5-the lake , [Sir Galahad]115-sir galahad , and all the other great names of the Table Round -- and how old , old , unspeakably old and faded and dry and musty and ancient [he]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about came to look as [he]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about went on ! Presently [he]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about turned to [me]0-i and said , just as one might speak of the weather , or any other common matter-- “ [You]0-i know about transmigration of [souls]4419-souls ; do [you]0-i know about transposition of epochs -- and bodies ? ”[0-i] [I]0-i said [I]0-i had not heard of it . [He]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about was so little interested -- just as when [people]357-people speak of the weather -- that [he]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about did not notice whether [I]0-i made [him]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about any answer or not . There was half a moment of silence , immediately interrupted by the droning voice of [the salaried cicerone]358-the salaried cicerone : “ Ancient hauberk , date of the sixth century , time of [King Arthur]116-arthur and the Round Table ; said to have belonged to [the knight Sir Sagramor le Desirous]117-sir sagramor ; observe the round hole through the chain - mail in the left breast ; ca n't be accounted for ; supposed to have been done with a bullet since invention of firearms -- perhaps maliciously by [[Cromwell]118-cromwell 's soldiers]4420-cromwell 's soldiers . ”[358-the salaried cicerone] [[My]0-i acquaintance]359-my acquaintance smiled -- not a modern smile , but one that must have gone out of general use many , many centuries ago -- and muttered apparently to [himself]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about : “ Wit [ye]0-i well , _ [I]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about saw it done _ . ”[349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about] Then , after a pause , added : “ [I]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about did it [myself]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about . ”[349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about] By the time [I]0-i had recovered from the electric surprise of this remark , [he]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about was gone . All that evening [I]0-i sat by [my]0-i fire at [the Warwick Arms]360-the warwick arms , steeped in a dream of the olden time , while the rain beat upon the windows , and the wind roared about the eaves and corners . From time to time [I]0-i dipped into old [Sir Thomas Malory]119-sir thomas malory 's enchanting book , and fed at its rich feast of prodigies and adventures , breathed in the fragrance of its obsolete names , and dreamed again . Midnight being come at length , [I]0-i read another tale , for a nightcap -- this which here follows , to wit : HOW [SIR LAUNCELOT SLEW TWO GIANTS]114-sir launcelot , AND MADE A CASTLE FREE [Anon withal]120-anon withal came there upon [him]349-the curious stranger whom i am going to talk about two great giants , well armed , all save the heads , with two horrible clubs in [their]361-their hands . [Sir Launcelot]114-sir launcelot put [his]114-sir launcelot shield afore [him]114-sir launcelot , and put the stroke away of [the one giant]362-the one giant , and with [his]114-sir launcelot sword [he]114-sir launcelot clave [his]114-sir launcelot head asunder . When [[his]114-sir launcelot fellow]363-his fellow saw that , [he]114-sir launcelot ran away as [he]114-sir launcelot were wood [ * demented ] , for fear of the horrible strokes , and [Sir Launcelot]114-sir launcelot after [him]114-sir launcelot with all [his]114-sir launcelot might , and smote [him]114-sir launcelot on the shoulder , and clave [him]114-sir launcelot to the middle . Then [Sir Launcelot]114-sir launcelot went into [the hall]364-the hall , and there came afore [him]114-sir launcelot [three score ladies and damsels]365-three score ladies and damsels , and [all]366-all kneeled unto [him]114-sir launcelot , and thanked [God]121-god and [him]114-sir launcelot of [their]365-three score ladies and damsels deliverance . For , [sir]367-sir , said [they]365-three score ladies and damsels , the most part of [us]368-we have been [here]369-here this seven year [[their]365-three score ladies and damsels prisoners]370-their prisoners , and [we]368-we have worked all manner of silk works for [our]368-we meat , and [we]368-we are [all great gentle - women born]371-all great gentle - women born , and blessed be the time , [knight]372-knight , that ever [thou]373-thou wert born ; for [thou]373-thou hast done the most worship that ever did knight in [the world]374-the world , that will [we]368-we bear record , and [we]368-we all pray [you]375-you to tell [us]368-we [your]375-you name , that [we]368-we may tell [[our]368-we friends who delivered [us]368-we out of [prison]377-prison]376-our friends who delivered us out of prison . [Fair damsels]378-fair damsels , [he]372-knight said , [my]0-i name is [Sir Launcelot du Lake]122-sir launcelot . And so [he]372-knight departed from [them]378-fair damsels and betaught [them]378-fair damsels unto [God]121-god . And then [he]372-knight mounted upon [his]372-knight horse , and rode into [many strange and wild countries]379-many strange and wild countries , and through [many waters]380-many waters and [valleys]381-valleys , and evil was [he]372-knight lodged . And at the last by fortune [him]372-knight happened against a night to come to [a fair courtilage]382-a fair courtilage , and therein [he]372-knight found [an old gentle - woman]383-an old gentle - woman that lodged [him]372-knight with a good - will , and there [he]372-knight had good cheer for [him]372-knight and [his]372-knight horse . And when time was , [[his]372-knight host]384-his host brought [him]372-knight into [a fair garret over the gate to [his]372-knight bed]385-a fair garret over the gate to his bed . There [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot unarmed [him]372-knight , and set [his]122-sir launcelot harness by [him]372-knight , and went to bed , and anon [he]372-knight fell on sleep . So , soon after there came [one on horseback]386-one on horseback , and knocked at the gate in great haste . And when [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot heard this [he]122-sir launcelot rose up , and looked out at the window , and saw by the moonlight [three knights]387-three knights come riding after [that one man]388-that one man , and all three lashed on [him]388-that one man at once with swords , and that [one knight]389-one knight turned on [them]387-three knights knightly again and defended [him]388-that one man . Truly , said [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot , yonder [one knight]389-one knight shall [I]0-i help , for it were shame for [me]0-i to see [three knights]387-three knights on one , and if [he]389-one knight be slain [I]0-i am partner of [his]389-one knight death . And therewith [he]122-sir launcelot took [his]122-sir launcelot harness and went out at a window by a sheet down to [the four knights]392-the four knights , and then [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot said on high , Turn [[you]392-the four knights knights]393-you knights unto [me]0-i , and leave [your]392-the four knights fighting with [that knight]394-that knight . And then [they]392-the four knights [all three]395-all three left [Sir Kay]123-sir kay , and turned unto [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot , and there began great battle , for [they]392-the four knights alight [all three]395-all three , and strake many strokes at [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot , and assailed [him]122-sir launcelot on every side . Then [Sir Kay]123-sir kay dressed [him]122-sir launcelot for to have holpen [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot . Nay , [sir]367-sir , said [he]123-sir kay , [I]0-i will none of [your]367-sir help , therefore as [ye]367-sir will have [my]0-i help let [me]0-i alone with [them]392-the four knights . [Sir Kay]123-sir kay for the pleasure of [the knight]398-the knight suffered [him]123-sir kay for to do [his]123-sir kay will , and so stood aside . And then anon within six strokes [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot had stricken [them]392-the four knights to [the earth]399-the earth . And then [they]392-the four knights [all three]395-all three cried , [Sir Knight]401-sir knight , [we]392-the four knights yield [us]392-the four knights unto [you]401-sir knight as [man of might matchless]402-man of might matchless . As to that , said [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot , [I]0-i will not take [your]367-sir yielding unto [me]0-i , but so that [ye]367-sir yield [you]367-sir unto [Sir Kay]123-sir kay [the seneschal]403-the seneschal , on that covenant [I]0-i will save [your]367-sir lives and else not . [Fair knight]404-fair knight , said [they]392-the four knights , that were [we]392-the four knights loath to do ; for as for [Sir Kay]123-sir kay [we]392-the four knights chased [him]123-sir kay hither , and had overcome [him]123-sir kay had [ye]367-sir not been ; therefore , to yield [us]392-the four knights unto [him]123-sir kay it were no reason . Well , as to that , said [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot , advise [you]367-sir well , for [ye]367-sir may choose whether [ye]367-sir will die or live , for an [ye]367-sir be yielden , it shall be unto [Sir Kay]123-sir kay . [Fair knight]404-fair knight , then [they]392-the four knights said , in saving [our]392-the four knights lives [we]392-the four knights will do as [thou]406-thou commandest [us]392-the four knights . Then shall [ye]367-sir , said [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot , on [Whitsunday]6-whitsunday next coming go unto [the court of [King Arthur]116-arthur]407-the court of king arthur , and there shall [ye]367-sir yield [you]367-sir unto [Queen Guenever]124-guenever , and put [you]367-sir all three in [her]124-guenever grace and mercy , and say that [Sir Kay]123-sir kay sent [you]367-sir thither to be [[her]124-guenever prisoners]408-her prisoners . On the morn [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot arose early , and left [Sir Kay]123-sir kay sleeping ; and [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot took [Sir Kay]123-sir kay 's armor and [his]123-sir kay shield and armed [him]123-sir kay , and so [he]122-sir launcelot went to [the stable]409-the stable and took [his]123-sir kay horse , and took [his]122-sir launcelot leave of [[his]122-sir launcelot host]384-his host , and so [he]122-sir launcelot departed . Then soon after arose [Sir Kay]123-sir kay and missed [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot ; and then [he]123-sir kay espied that [he]123-sir kay had [his]123-sir kay armor and [his]123-sir kay horse . Now by [my]0-i faith [I]0-i know well that [he]123-sir kay will grieve some of [the court of [King Arthur]116-arthur]407-the court of king arthur ; for on [him]123-sir kay [knights]412-knights will be bold , and deem that it is [I]0-i , and that will beguile [them]412-knights ; and because of [his]123-sir kay armor and shield [I]0-i am sure [I]0-i shall ride in peace . And then soon after departed [Sir Kay]123-sir kay , and thanked [[his]123-sir kay host]384-his host . As [I]0-i laid the book down there was a knock at the door , and [[my]0-i stranger]414-my stranger came in . [I]0-i gave [him]414-my stranger a pipe and a chair , and made [him]414-my stranger welcome . [I]0-i also comforted [him]414-my stranger with a hot Scotch whisky ; gave [him]414-my stranger another one ; then still another -- hoping always for [his]414-my stranger story . After [a fourth persuader]415-a fourth persuader , [he]414-my stranger drifted into it [himself]414-my stranger , in a quite simple and natural way : [THE STRANGER]416-the stranger 'S HISTORY [I]0-i am [an American]417-an american . [I]0-i was born and reared in [Hartford]3-hartford , in [the State of Connecticut]418-the state of connecticut -- anyway , just over [the river]419-the river , in [the country]420-the country . So [I]0-i am [a Yankee of the Yankees]421-a yankee of the yankees -- and practical ; yes , and nearly barren of sentiment , [I]0-i suppose -- or poetry , in other words . [[My]0-i father]422-my father was [a blacksmith]423-a blacksmith , [[my]0-i uncle]424-my uncle was [a horse doctor]425-a horse doctor , and [I]0-i was both , along at first . Then [I]0-i went over to [the great arms factory]426-the great arms factory and learned [my]0-i real trade ; learned all there was to it ; learned to make everything : guns , revolvers , cannon , boilers , engines , all sorts of labor - saving machinery . Why , [I]0-i could make anything [a body]427-a body wanted -- anything in [the world]374-the world , it did n't make any difference what ; and if there was n't any quick new - fangled way to make a thing , [I]0-i could invent one -- and do it as easy as rolling off a log . [I]0-i became [head superintendent]429-head superintendent ; had [a couple of thousand men under [me]0-i]430-a couple of thousand men under me . Well , [a man like that]431-a man like that is [a man that is full of fight]432-a man that is full of fight -- that goes without saying . With [a couple of thousand rough men under one]433-a couple of thousand rough men under one , [one]434-one has plenty of that sort of amusement . [I]0-i had , anyway . At last [I]0-i met [my]0-i match , and [I]0-i got [my]0-i dose . It was during a misunderstanding conducted with crowbars with [a fellow [we]436-we used to call [Hercules]125-hercules]435-a fellow we used to call hercules . [He]435-a fellow we used to call hercules laid [me]0-i out with a crusher alongside the head that made everything crack , and seemed to spring every joint in [my]0-i skull and made it overlap its neighbor . Then [the world]374-the world went out in darkness , and [I]0-i did n't feel anything more , and did n't know anything at all --at least for a while . When [I]0-i came to again , [I]0-i was sitting under an oak tree , on the grass , with [a whole beautiful and broad country landscape all to [myself]0-i]438-a whole beautiful and broad country landscape all to myself -- nearly . Not entirely ; for there was a fellow on a horse , looking down at [me]0-i -- [a fellow fresh out of a picture - book]439-a fellow fresh out of a picture - book . [He]435-a fellow we used to call hercules was in old - time iron armor from head to heel , with a helmet on [his]435-a fellow we used to call hercules head the shape of a nail - keg with slits in it ; and [he]435-a fellow we used to call hercules had a shield , and a sword , and a prodigious spear ; and [his]435-a fellow we used to call hercules horse had armor on , too , and a steel horn projecting from [his]435-a fellow we used to call hercules forehead , and gorgeous red and green silk trappings that hung down all around [him]435-a fellow we used to call hercules like a bedquilt , nearly to the ground . “ Fair sir , will [ye]0-i just ? ”[440-this fellow] said [this fellow]440-this fellow . “ Will [I]440-this fellow which ? ”[440-this fellow] “ Will [ye]0-i try a passage of arms for land or [lady]4421-lady or for-- ”[440-this fellow] “ What are [you]441-this man giving [me]0-i ? ”[0-i] [I]0-i said . “ Get along back to [[your]441-this man circus]4422-your circus , or [I]0-i 'll report [you]441-this man . ”[0-i] Now what does [this man]441-this man do but fall back a couple of hundred yards and then come rushing at [me]0-i as hard as [he]441-this man could tear , with [his]441-this man nail - keg bent down nearly to [his]441-this man horse 's neck and [his]441-this man long spear pointed straight ahead . [I]0-i saw [he]441-this man meant business , so [I]0-i was up the tree when [he]441-this man arrived . [We]443-we marched comfortably along , through glades and over brooks which [I]0-i could not remember to have seen before -- which puzzled [me]0-i and made [me]0-i wonder -- and yet [we]443-we did not come to any circus or sign of [a circus]444-a circus . So [I]0-i gave up the idea of a circus , and concluded [he]441-this man was from [an asylum]445-an asylum . But [we]443-we never came to [an asylum]445-an asylum -- so [I]0-i was up a stump , as [you]447-you may say . [I]0-i asked [him]441-this man how far [we]443-we were from [Hartford]3-hartford . [CAMELOT]7-camelot “ [Camelot]7-camelot -- [Camelot]7-camelot , ”[0-i] said [I]0-i to [myself]0-i . “ [I]0-i do n't seem to remember hearing of it before . Name of [the asylum]4424-the asylum , likely . ”[0-i] It was [a soft , reposeful summer landscape , as lovely as a dream]457-a soft , reposeful summer landscape , as lovely as a dream , and as lonesome as [Sunday]127-sunday . The air was full of the smell of flowers , and the buzzing of insects , and the twittering of birds , and there were [no people]458-no people , no [wagons]459-wagons , there was no stir of life , nothing going on . [The road]460-the road was mainly [a winding path with hoof - prints]461-a winding path with hoof - prints in it , and now and then a faint trace of wheels on either side in the grass -- wheels that apparently had a tire as broad as one 's hand . Presently [a fair slip of a girl , about ten years old]462-a fair slip of a girl , about ten years old , with a cataract of golden hair streaming down over [her]463-she shoulders , came along . Around [her]463-she head [she]463-she wore a hoop of flame - red poppies . It was as sweet an outfit as ever [I]0-i saw , what there was of it . [She]463-she walked indolently along , with a mind at rest , its peace reflected in [her]463-she innocent face . [The circus man]464-the circus man paid no attention to [her]463-she ; did n't even seem to see [her]463-she . And [she]463-she -- [she]463-she was no more startled at [his]464-the circus man fantastic make - up than if [she]463-she was used to [his]464-the circus man like every day of [her]463-she life . [She]463-she was going by as indifferently as [she]463-she might have gone by a couple of cows ; but when [she]463-she happened to notice [me]0-i , _ then _ there was a change ! Up went [her]463-she hands , and [she]463-she was turned to stone ; [her]463-she mouth dropped open , [her]463-she eyes stared wide and timorously , [she]463-she was the picture of astonished curiosity touched with fear . And there [she]463-she stood gazing , in a sort of stupefied fascination , till [we]465-we turned a corner of the wood and were lost to [her]463-she view . That [she]463-she should be startled at [me]0-i instead of at [the other man]466-the other man , was too many for [me]0-i ; [I]0-i could n't make head or tail of it . And that [she]463-she should seem to consider [me]0-i a spectacle , and totally overlook [her]463-she own merits in that respect , was another puzzling thing , and a display of magnanimity , too , that was surprising in one so young . There was food for thought here . [I]0-i moved along as one in a dream . As [we]465-we approached [the town]467-the town , signs of life began to appear . At intervals [we]465-we passed [a wretched cabin]468-a wretched cabin , with a thatched roof , and about [it]468-a wretched cabin small fields and [garden patches in an indifferent state of cultivation]469-garden patches in an indifferent state of cultivation . There were [people]357-people , too ; [brawny men]471-brawny men , with long , coarse , uncombed hair that hung down over [their]471-brawny men faces and made [them]471-brawny men look like animals . [They]471-brawny men and [the women]472-the women , as a rule , wore a coarse tow - linen robe that came well below the knee , and a rude sort of sandal , and [many]473-many wore an iron collar . [The small boys]474-the small boys and [girls]475-girls were always naked ; but [nobody]476-nobody seemed to know it . In [the town]467-the town were [some substantial windowless houses of stone scattered among a wilderness of thatched cabins]483-some substantial windowless houses of stone scattered among a wilderness of thatched cabins ; [the streets]484-the streets were mere crooked alleys , and unpaved ; [troops of dogs]485-troops of dogs and [nude children]486-nude children played in the sun and made life and noise ; hogs roamed and rooted contentedly about , and one of [them]487-them lay in a reeking wallow in the middle of [the main thoroughfare]488-the main thoroughfare and suckled [[her]489-her family]490-her family . Presently there was a distant blare of military music ; it came nearer , still nearer , and soon [a noble cavalcade]491-a noble cavalcade wound into view , glorious with plumed helmets and flashing mail and flaunting banners and rich doublets and horse - cloths and gilded spearheads ; and through the muck and swine , and [naked brats]492-naked brats , and joyous dogs , and [shabby huts]493-shabby huts , it took its gallant way , and in its wake [we]494-we followed . Followed through [one winding alley]495-one winding alley and then another,--and climbing , always climbing -- till at last [we]494-we gained the breezy height where [the huge castle]496-the huge castle stood . There was an exchange of bugle blasts ; then a parley from the walls , where [men - at - arms]497-men - at - arms , in hauberk and morion , marched back and forth with halberd at shoulder under flapping banners with the rude figure of a dragon displayed upon them ; and then the great gates were flung open , the drawbridge was lowered , and the head of [the cavalcade]498-the cavalcade swept forward under the frowning arches ; and [we]494-we , following , soon found [ourselves]494-we in [a great paved court]499-a great paved court , with towers and turrets stretching up into the blue air on all the four sides ; and all about [us]494-we the dismount was going on , and much greeting and ceremony , and running to and fro , and a gay display of moving and intermingling colors , and an altogether pleasant stir and noise and confusion . [They]4435-my friends will not be born for more than thirteen hundred years yet . ”[0-i] [I]0-i seemed to believe [the boy]506-the boy , [I]0-i did n't know why . _ Something _ in [me]0-i seemed to believe [him]506-the boy -- [my]0-i consciousness , as [you]507-you may say ; but [my]0-i reason did n't . [I]0-i did n't know how to go about satisfying it , because [I]0-i knew that the testimony of [men]508-men would n't serve -- [my]0-i reason would say [they]508-men were [lunatics]509-lunatics , and throw out [their]508-men evidence . But all of a sudden [I]0-i stumbled on the very thing , just by luck . [I]0-i knew that the only total eclipse of the sun in the first half of the sixth century occurred on the 21st of June , A.D. 528 , O.S. , and began at 3 minutes after 12 noon . [I]0-i also knew that no total eclipse of the sun was due in what to _ [me]0-i _ was the present year -- [i.e.]510-i.e. , 1879 . So , if [I]0-i could keep [my]0-i anxiety and curiosity from eating the heart out of [me]0-i for forty - eight hours , [I]0-i should then find out for certain whether [this boy]511-this boy was telling [me]0-i the truth or not . Wherefore , being [a practical Connecticut man]512-a practical connecticut man , [I]0-i now shoved this whole problem clear out of [my]0-i mind till its appointed day and hour should come , in order that [I]0-i might turn all [my]0-i attention to the circumstances of the present moment , and be alert and ready to make the most out of them that could be made . One thing at a time , is [my]0-i motto -- and just play that thing for all it is worth , even if it 's only two pair and a jack . [I]0-i made up [my]0-i mind to two things : if it was still the nineteenth century and [I]0-i was among [lunatics]509-lunatics and could n't get away , [I]0-i would presently boss [that asylum]514-that asylum or know the reason why ; and if , on the other hand , it was really the sixth century , all right , [I]0-i did n't want any softer thing : [I]0-i would boss [the whole country]515-the whole country inside of three months ; for [I]0-i judged [I]0-i would have the start of [the best - educated man in [the kingdom]517-the kingdom]516-the best - educated man in the kingdom by a matter of thirteen hundred years and upward . The page said , further , that dinner was about ended in [the great hall]524-the great hall by this time , and that as soon as the sociability and the heavy drinking should begin , [Sir Kay]123-sir kay would have [me]0-i in and exhibit [me]0-i before [King Arthur]116-arthur and [[his]116-arthur illustrious knights]525-his illustrious knights seated at the Table Round , and would brag about [his]123-sir kay exploit in capturing [me]0-i , and would probably exaggerate the facts a little , but it would n't be good form for [me]0-i to correct [him]123-sir kay , and not over safe , either ; and when [I]0-i was done being exhibited , then ho for [the dungeon]526-the dungeon ; but [he]123-sir kay , [Clarence]131-clarence , would find a way to come and see [me]0-i every now and then , and cheer [me]0-i up , and help [me]0-i get word to [[my]0-i friends]4435-my friends . Get word to [[my]0-i friends]4435-my friends ! [I]0-i thanked [him]123-sir kay ; [I]0-i could n't do less ; and about this time [a lackey]529-a lackey came to say [I]0-i was wanted ; so [Clarence]131-clarence led [me]0-i in and took [me]0-i off to one side and sat down by [me]0-i . Well , it was a curious kind of spectacle , and interesting . It was an immense place , and rather naked -- yes , and full of loud contrasts . [It]530-it was very , very lofty ; so lofty that the banners depending from the arched beams and girders away up there floated in a sort of twilight ; there was a stone - railed gallery at each end , high up , with [musicians]531-musicians in the one , and [women]532-women , clothed in stunning colors , in the other . The floor was of big stone flags laid in black and white squares , rather battered by age and use , and needing repair . As to ornament , there was n't any , strictly speaking ; though on the walls hung some huge tapestries which were probably taxed as works of art ; battle - pieces , they were , with horses shaped like those which [children]533-children cut out of paper or create in gingerbread ; with [men]508-men on [them]535-them in scale armor whose scales are represented by round holes -- so that [the man]536-the man 's coat looks as if it had been done with a biscuit - punch . There was a fireplace big enough to camp in ; and [its]537-its projecting sides and hood , of carved and pillared stonework , had the look of a cathedral door . Along the walls stood [men - at - arms]497-men - at - arms , in breastplate and morion , with halberds for [their]497-men - at - arms only weapon --rigid as statues ; and that is what [they]497-men - at - arms looked like . In the middle of [this groined and vaulted public square]539-this groined and vaulted public square was an oaken table which [they]497-men - at - arms called the Table Round . It was as large as a circus ring ; and around [it]537-its sat [a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one 's eyes to look at [them]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one . [They]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one wore [their]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one plumed hats , right along , except that whenever [one]434-one addressed [himself]434-one directly to [the king]4445-the king , [he]434-one lifted [his]434-one hat a trifle just as [he]434-one was beginning [his]434-one remark . Mainly [they]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one were drinking -- from entire ox horns ; but a few were still munching bread or gnawing beef bones . There was about an average of two dogs to [one man]543-one man ; and these sat in expectant attitudes till a spent bone was flung to [them]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one , and then [they]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one went for it by brigades and divisions , with a rush , and there ensued a fight which filled the prospect with a tumultuous chaos of plunging heads and bodies and flashing tails , and the storm of howlings and barkings deafened all speech for the time ; but that was no matter , for the dog - fight was always a bigger interest anyway ; [the men]544-the men rose , sometimes , to observe it the better and bet on it , and [the ladies]545-the ladies and [the musicians]546-the musicians stretched [themselves]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one out over [their]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one balusters with the same object ; and [all]366-all broke into delighted ejaculations from time to time . In the end , the winning dog stretched [himself]434-one out comfortably with [his]434-one bone between [his]434-one paws , and proceeded to growl over it , and gnaw it , and grease the floor with it , just as [fifty others]548-fifty others were already doing ; and [the rest of [the court]550-the court]549-the rest of the court resumed [their]549-the rest of the court previous industries and entertainments . As a rule , the speech and behavior of [these people]551-these people were gracious and courtly ; and [I]0-i noticed that [they]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one were [good and serious listeners]552-good and serious listeners when [anybody]553-anybody was telling anything -- [I]0-i mean in a dog - fightless interval . And plainly , too , [they]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one were [a childlike and innocent lot]554-a childlike and innocent lot ; telling lies of the stateliest pattern with a most gentle and winning naivety , and ready and willing to listen to [anybody else]555-anybody else 's lie , and believe it , too . It was hard to associate [them]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one with anything cruel or dreadful ; and yet [they]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one dealt in tales of blood and suffering with a guileless relish that made [me]0-i almost forget to shudder . [I]0-i was not [the only prisoner present]556-the only prisoner present . There were twenty or more . Poor devils , many of [them]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one were maimed , hacked , carved , in a frightful way ; and [their]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one hair , [their]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one faces , [their]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one clothing , were caked with black and stiffened drenchings of blood . [They]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one were suffering sharp physical pain , of course ; and weariness , and hunger and thirst , no doubt ; and at least [none]557-none had given [them]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one the comfort of a wash , or even the poor charity of a lotion for [their]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one wounds ; yet [you]558-you never heard [them]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one utter a moan or a groan , or saw [them]540-a great company of men dressed in such various and splendid colors that it hurt one show any sign of restlessness , or any disposition to complain . The thought was forced upon [me]0-i : “ [The rascals--_they]132-the rascals--_they _ have served [other people]4446-other people so in [their]132-the rascals--_they day ; it being [their]132-the rascals--_they own turn , now , [they]132-the rascals--_they were not expecting any better treatment than this ; so [their]132-the rascals--_they philosophical bearing is not an outcome of mental training , intellectual fortitude , reasoning ; it is mere animal training ; [they]132-the rascals--_they are [white Indians]4447-white indians . ”[0-i] CHAPTER III KNIGHTS OF THE TABLE ROUND Mainly the Round Table talk was monologues -- narrative accounts of the adventures in which [these prisoners]559-these prisoners were captured and [[their]559-these prisoners friends]560-their friends and [backers]561-backers killed and stripped of [their]559-these prisoners steeds and armor . As a general thing -- as far as [I]0-i could make out -- these murderous adventures were not forays undertaken to avenge injuries , nor to settle old disputes or sudden fallings out ; no , as a rule they were simply duels between [strangers]562-strangers -- duels between [people who had never even been introduced to each other , and between whom existed no cause of offense whatever]563-people who had never even been introduced to each other , and between whom existed no cause of offense whatever . Many a time [I]0-i had seen [a couple of boys]564-a couple of boys , [strangers]562-strangers , meet by chance , and say simultaneously , “ [I]562-strangers can lick [you]569-you , ”[562-strangers] and go at it on the spot ; but [I]0-i had always imagined until now that that sort of thing belonged to [children]533-children only , and was a sign and mark of childhood ; but here were these big boobies sticking to it and taking pride in it clear up into full age and beyond . Yet there was something very engaging about [these great simple - hearted creatures]567-these great simple - hearted creatures , something attractive and lovable . There did not seem to be brains enough in [the entire nursery]568-the entire nursery , so to speak , to bait a fish - hook with ; but [you]569-you did n't seem to mind that , after a little , because [you]569-you soon saw that brains were not needed in a society like that , and indeed would have marred it , hindered it , spoiled its symmetry -- perhaps rendered its existence impossible . There was a fine manliness observable in almost every face ; and in some a certain loftiness and sweetness that rebuked [your]569-you belittling criticisms and stilled them . A most noble benignity and purity reposed in the countenance of [him]570-him [they]571-they called [Sir Galahad]115-sir galahad , and likewise in [the king]4445-the king 's also ; and there was majesty and greatness in the giant frame and high bearing of [[Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot of [the Lake]5-the lake]573-sir launcelot of the lake . There was presently an incident which centered the general interest upon this [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot . At a sign from [a sort of master of ceremonies]574-a sort of master of ceremonies , [six or eight of [the prisoners]576-the prisoners]575-six or eight of the prisoners rose and came forward in a body and knelt on the floor and lifted up [their]575-six or eight of the prisoners hands toward [[the ladies]545-the ladies ' gallery]578-the ladies ' gallery and begged the grace of a word with [the queen]579-the queen . [The most conspicuously situated lady in that massed flower - bed of feminine show and finery]580-the most conspicuously situated lady in that massed flower - bed of feminine show and finery inclined [her]580-the most conspicuously situated lady in that massed flower - bed of feminine show and finery head by way of assent , and then [the spokesman of [the prisoners]576-the prisoners]581-the spokesman of the prisoners delivered [himself]581-the spokesman of the prisoners and [[his]581-the spokesman of the prisoners fellows]583-his fellows into [her]580-the most conspicuously situated lady in that massed flower - bed of feminine show and finery hands for free pardon , ransom , captivity , or death , as [she]580-the most conspicuously situated lady in that massed flower - bed of feminine show and finery in [her]580-the most conspicuously situated lady in that massed flower - bed of feminine show and finery good pleasure might elect ; and this , as [he]581-the spokesman of the prisoners said , [he]581-the spokesman of the prisoners was doing by command of [Sir Kay]123-sir kay the Seneschal , whose prisoners [they]576-the prisoners were , [he]581-the spokesman of the prisoners having vanquished [them]576-the prisoners by [his]581-the spokesman of the prisoners single might and prowess in sturdy conflict in the field . Surprise and astonishment flashed from face to face all over [the house]584-the house ; [the queen]579-the queen 's gratified smile faded out at the name of [Sir Kay]123-sir kay , and [she]579-the queen looked disappointed ; and [the page]586-the page whispered in [my]0-i ear with an accent and manner expressive of extravagant derision-- “ [Sir _ Kay]123-sir kay _ , forsooth ! Oh , call [me]586-the page pet names , [dearest]4448-dearest , call [me]586-the page [a marine]4449-a marine ! In twice a thousand years shall the unholy invention of [man]4450-man labor at odds to beget [the fellow]4451-the fellow to this majestic lie ! ”[586-the page] Every eye was fastened with severe inquiry upon [Sir Kay]123-sir kay . But [he]123-sir kay was equal to the occasion . [He]123-sir kay got up and played [his]123-sir kay hand like [a major]587-a major -- and took every trick . [He]123-sir kay said [he]123-sir kay would state the case exactly according to the facts ; [he]123-sir kay would tell the simple straightforward tale , without comment of [his]123-sir kay own ; “ and then , ”[123-sir kay] said [he]123-sir kay , “ if [ye]4452-ye find glory and honor due , [ye]4452-ye will give it unto [him]123-sir kay who is [the mightiest man of [his]123-sir kay [hands that ever bare shield or strake with sword in the ranks of Christian battle]4454-hands that ever bare shield or strake with sword in the ranks of christian battle]4453-the mightiest man of his hands that ever bare shield or strake with sword in the ranks of christian battle -- even [him]123-sir kay that sitteth there ! ”[123-sir kay] and [he]123-sir kay pointed to [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot . Ah , [he]123-sir kay fetched [them]588-them ; it was a rattling good stroke . Then [he]123-sir kay went on and told how [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot , seeking adventures , some brief time gone by , killed [seven giants]589-seven giants at one sweep of [his]122-sir launcelot sword , and set [a hundred and forty - two captive maidens]590-a hundred and forty - two captive maidens free ; and then went further , still seeking adventures , and found [him]122-sir launcelot ( [Sir Kay]123-sir kay ) fighting a desperate fight against [nine foreign knights]591-nine foreign knights , and straightway took the battle solely into [his]122-sir launcelot own hands , and conquered [the nine]592-the nine ; and that night [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot rose quietly , and dressed [him]122-sir launcelot in [Sir Kay]123-sir kay 's armor and took [Sir Kay]123-sir kay 's horse and gat [him]122-sir launcelot away into [distant lands]593-distant lands , and vanquished [sixteen knights]594-sixteen knights in one pitched battle and thirty - four in another ; and all these and the former nine [he]122-sir launcelot made to swear that about [Whitsuntide]133-whitsuntide [they]592-the nine would ride to [[Arthur]116-arthur 's court]595-arthur 's court and yield [them]592-the nine to [Queen Guenever]124-guenever 's hands as captives of [Sir Kay]123-sir kay [the Seneschal]403-the seneschal , spoil of [his]123-sir kay knightly prowess ; and now here were [these half dozen]597-these half dozen , and [the rest]598-the rest would be along as soon as [they]598-the rest might be healed of [their]598-the rest desperate wounds . Well , it was touching to see [the queen]579-the queen blush and smile , and look embarrassed and happy , and fling furtive glances at [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot that would have got [him]122-sir launcelot shot in [Arkansas]9-arkansas , to a dead certainty . [Everybody]600-everybody praised the valor and magnanimity of [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot ; and as for [me]0-i , [I]0-i was perfectly amazed , that [one man]543-one man , all by [himself]543-one man , should have been able to beat down and capture [such battalions of [practiced fighters]603-practiced fighters]602-such battalions of practiced fighters . [I]0-i said as much to [Clarence]131-clarence ; but [this mocking featherhead]604-this mocking featherhead only said : “ An Sir [Kay]123-sir kay had had time to get another skin of sour wine into [him]506-the boy , [ye]0-i had seen [the accompt]4455-the accompt doubled . ”[604-this mocking featherhead] [I]0-i looked at [the boy]506-the boy in sorrow ; and as [I]0-i looked [I]0-i saw the cloud of a deep despondency settle upon [his]506-the boy countenance . [I]0-i followed the direction of [his]506-the boy eye , and saw that [a very old and white - bearded man , clothed in a flowing black gown]606-a very old and white - bearded man , clothed in a flowing black gown , had risen and was standing at the table upon unsteady legs , and feebly swaying [his]506-the boy ancient head and surveying [the company]607-the company with [his]506-the boy watery and wandering eye . The same suffering look that was in [the page]586-the page 's face was observable in all the faces around -- the look of [dumb creatures who know that they must endure and make no moan]609-dumb creatures who know that they must endure and make no moan . “ [Marry]128-marry , [we]4456-we shall have it again , ”[506-the boy] sighed [the boy]506-the boy ; “ that same old weary tale that [he]506-the boy hath told a thousand times in the same words , and that [he]506-the boy _ will _ tell till [he]506-the boy dieth , every time [he]506-the boy hath gotten [his]506-the boy barrel full and feeleth [his]506-the boy exaggeration - mill a - working . Would [God]121-god [I]506-the boy had died or [I]506-the boy saw this day ! ”[506-the boy] “ Who is it ? ”[506-the boy] “ [Merlin]134-merlin , [the mighty liar and magician]4457-the mighty liar and magician , [perdition]4458-perdition singe [him]506-the boy for the weariness [he]506-the boy worketh with [his]506-the boy one tale ! But that [men]508-men fear [him]506-the boy for that [he]506-the boy hath the storms and the lightnings and all the devils that be in hell at [his]506-the boy beck and call , [they]508-men would have dug [his]506-the boy entrails out these many years ago to get at that tale and squelch it . [He]506-the boy telleth it always in the third person , making believe [he]506-the boy is too modest to glorify [himself]506-the boy -- maledictions light upon [him]506-the boy , misfortune be [his]506-the boy dole ! [Good friend]4460-good friend , prithee call [me]506-the boy for evensong . ”[506-the boy] [The boy]506-the boy nestled [himself]506-the boy upon [my]0-i shoulder and pretended to go to sleep . [The old man]612-the old man began [his]612-the old man tale ; and presently [the lad]613-the lad was asleep in reality ; so also were the dogs , and [the court]550-the court , [the lackeys]615-the lackeys , and the files of [men - at - arms]497-men - at - arms . The droning voice droned on ; a soft snoring arose on all sides and supported it like a deep and subdued accompaniment of wind instruments . Some heads were bowed upon folded arms , [some]617-some lay back with open mouths that issued unconscious music ; the flies buzzed and bit , unmolested , the rats swarmed softly out from a hundred holes , and pattered about , and made [themselves]618-themselves at [home]619-home everywhere ; and [one of [them]618-themselves]620-one of them sat up like a squirrel on [the king]4445-the king 's head and held a bit of cheese in its hands and nibbled it , and dribbled the crumbs in [the king]4445-the king 's face with naive and impudent irreverence . It was a tranquil scene , and restful to the weary eye and the jaded spirit . This was [the old man]612-the old man 's tale . [He]612-the old man said : “ Right so [the king]4445-the king and [Merlin]134-merlin departed , and went until [an hermit that was a good man and a great leech]4462-an hermit that was a good man and a great leech . So [the hermit]4463-the hermit searched all [his]4445-the king wounds and gave [him]4445-the king good salves ; so [the king]4445-the king was there three days , and then were [his]4445-the king wounds well amended that [he]4445-the king might ride and go , and so departed . And as [they]4465-they rode , [Arthur]116-arthur said , [I]612-the old man have no sword . No force , * [ * Footnote from M.T. : No matter . ] said [Merlin]134-merlin , hereby is a sword that shall be [yours]4466-yours and [I]612-the old man may . So [they]4465-they rode till [they]4465-they came to [a lake]4467-a lake , the which was [a fair water]4468-a fair water and broad , and in the midst of [the lake]4469-the lake [Arthur]116-arthur was ware of an arm clothed in white samite , that held a fair sword in that hand . [Lo]135-lo , said [Merlin]134-merlin , yonder is that sword that [I]612-the old man spake of . With that [they]4465-they saw [a damsel]4470-a damsel going upon [the lake]4469-the lake . What damsel is that ? said [Arthur]116-arthur . That is [the Lady of [the lake]4469-the lake]4472-the lady of the lake , said [Merlin]134-merlin ; and within [that lake]4474-that lake is [a rock]4475-a rock , and therein is as fair a place as [any on earth]4476-any on earth , and richly beseen , and [this damsel]4477-this damsel will come to [you]4478-you anon , and then speak [ye]4478-you fair to [her]4477-this damsel that [she]4477-this damsel will give [you]4478-you that sword . [I]612-the old man would it were [mine]612-the old man , for [I]612-the old man have no sword . So [Sir Arthur]137-arthur and [Merlin]134-merlin alight , and tied [their]4484-they horses to two trees , and so [they]4484-they went into [the ship]4485-the ship , and when [they]4484-they came to the sword that the hand held , [Sir Arthur]137-arthur took it up by the handles , and took it with [him]137-arthur . And the arm and the hand went under the water ; and so [they]4484-they came unto [the land]4486-the land and rode forth . And then [Sir Arthur]137-arthur saw [a rich pavilion]4487-a rich pavilion . What signifieth [yonder pavilion]4488-yonder pavilion ? It is [[the knight]398-the knight 's pavilion]4490-the knight 's pavilion , said [Merlin]134-merlin , that [ye]137-arthur fought with last , [Sir Pellinore]138-sir pellinore , but [he]398-the knight is out , [he]398-the knight is not [there]4491-there ; [he]398-the knight hath ado with [a knight of yours]4492-a knight of yours , that hight [Egglame]139-egglame , and [they]4484-they have fought together , but at the last [Egglame]139-egglame fled , and else [he]139-egglame had been dead , and [he]139-egglame hath chased [him]139-egglame even to [Carlion]10-carlion , and [we]4493-we shall meet with [him]398-the knight anon in [the highway]4494-the highway . That is well said , said [Arthur]137-arthur , now have [I]612-the old man a sword , now will [I]612-the old man wage battle with [him]398-the knight , and be avenged on [him]398-the knight . [Sir]367-sir , [ye]367-sir shall not so , said [Merlin]134-merlin , for [the knight]398-the knight is weary of fighting and chasing , so that [ye]367-sir shall have no worship to have ado with [him]398-the knight ; also , [he]398-the knight will not lightly be matched of [one knight living]4497-one knight living ; and therefore it is [my]612-the old man counsel , let [him]398-the knight pass , for [he]398-the knight shall do [you]367-sir good service in short time , and [[his]398-the knight sons]4498-his sons , after [his]398-the knight days . Also [ye]367-sir shall see that day in short space [ye]367-sir shall be right glad to give [him]398-the knight [[your]367-sir sister]4499-your sister to [we]4500-they d. When [I]612-the old man see [him]398-the knight , [I]612-the old man will do as [ye]367-sir advise [me]612-the old man , said [Arthur]137-arthur . Then [Sir Arthur]137-arthur looked on the sword , and liked it passing well . Whether liketh [you]367-sir better , said [Merlin]134-merlin , the sword or the scabbard ? [Me]612-the old man liketh better the sword , said [Arthur]137-arthur . [Ye]367-sir are more unwise , said [Merlin]134-merlin , for the scabbard is worth ten of the sword , for while [ye]367-sir have the scabbard upon [you]367-sir [ye]367-sir shall never lose no blood , be [ye]367-sir never so sore wounded ; therefore , keep well the scabbard always with [you]367-sir . So [they]4500-they rode into [Carlion]10-carlion , and by the way [they]4500-they met with [Sir Pellinore]138-sir pellinore ; but [Merlin]134-merlin had done such a craft that [Pellinore]138-sir pellinore saw not [Arthur]137-arthur , and [he]134-merlin passed by without any words . [I]612-the old man marvel , said [Arthur]137-arthur , that [the knight]398-the knight would not speak . [Sir]367-sir , said [Merlin]134-merlin , [he]134-merlin saw [you]367-sir not ; for and [he]134-merlin had seen [you]367-sir [ye]367-sir had not lightly departed . So [they]4500-they came unto [Carlion]10-carlion , whereof [[his]134-merlin knights]4503-his knights were passing glad . And when [they]4500-they heard of [his]134-merlin adventures [they]4500-they marveled that [he]134-merlin would jeopard [his]134-merlin person so alone . But [all men of worship]4504-all men of worship said it was merry to be under [such a chieftain]4505-such a chieftain that would put [his]134-merlin person in adventure as [other poor knights]4506-other poor knights did . ”[612-the old man] CHAPTER IV [SIR DINADAN THE HUMORIST]140-sir dinadan It seemed to [me]0-i that this quaint lie was most simply and beautifully told ; but then [I]0-i had heard it only once , and that makes a difference ; it was pleasant to the others when it was fresh , no doubt . [Sir Dinadan the Humorist]140-sir dinadan was the first to awake , and [he]140-sir dinadan soon roused the rest with a practical joke of a sufficiently poor quality . [He]140-sir dinadan tied some metal mugs to a dog 's tail and turned [him]624-him loose , and [he]140-sir dinadan tore around and around [the place]448-the place in a frenzy of fright , with all the other dogs bellowing after [him]140-sir dinadan and battering and crashing against everything that came in [their]626-their way and making altogether a chaos of confusion and a most deafening din and turmoil ; at which [every man and woman of the multitude]627-every man and woman of the multitude laughed till the tears flowed , and some fell out of [their]628-their chairs and wallowed on the floor in ecstasy . It was just like [so many children]629-so many children . [Sir Dinadan]140-sir dinadan was so proud of [his]140-sir dinadan exploit that [he]140-sir dinadan could not keep from telling over and over again , to weariness , how the immortal idea happened to occur to [him]140-sir dinadan ; and as is the way with [humorists of [his]140-sir dinadan breed]630-humorists of his breed , [he]140-sir dinadan was still laughing at it after [everybody else]631-everybody else had got through . [He]140-sir dinadan was so set up that [he]140-sir dinadan concluded to make a speech --of course a humorous speech . [I]0-i think [I]0-i never heard so many old played - out jokes strung together in [my]0-i life . [He]140-sir dinadan was worse than [the minstrels]632-the minstrels , worse than [the clown in the circus]633-the clown in the circus . It seemed peculiarly sad to sit [here]369-here , thirteen hundred years before [I]0-i was born , and listen again to poor , flat , worm - eaten jokes that had given [me]0-i the dry gripes when [I]0-i was [a boy thirteen hundred years afterwards]635-a boy thirteen hundred years afterwards . It about convinced [me]0-i that there is n't any such thing as a new joke possible . [Everybody]600-everybody laughed at these antiquities --but then [they]600-everybody always do ; [I]0-i had noticed that , centuries later . However , of course [the scoffer]637-the scoffer did n't laugh -- [I]0-i mean [the boy]506-the boy . No , [he]140-sir dinadan scoffed ; there was n't anything [he]140-sir dinadan would n't scoff at . [He]140-sir dinadan said the most of [Sir Dinadan]140-sir dinadan 's jokes were rotten and the rest were petrified . [I]0-i said “ petrified ”[0-i] was good ; as [I]0-i believed , [myself]0-i , that the only right way to classify the majestic ages of some of those jokes was by geologic periods . But that neat idea hit [the boy]506-the boy in a blank place , for geology had n't been invented yet . However , [I]0-i made a note of the remark , and calculated to educate [the commonwealth]640-the commonwealth up to it if [I]0-i pulled through . It is no use to throw a good thing away merely because the market is n't ripe yet . Now [Sir Kay]123-sir kay arose and began to fire up on [[his]123-sir kay history - mill]641-his history - mill with [me]0-i for fuel . It was time for [me]0-i to feel serious , and [I]0-i did . [Sir Kay]123-sir kay told how [he]123-sir kay had encountered [me]0-i in [a far land of barbarians]642-a far land of barbarians , who all wore the same ridiculous garb that [I]0-i did -- a garb that was a work of enchantment , and intended to make [the wearer secure from hurt by human hands]643-the wearer secure from hurt by human hands . However [he]123-sir kay had nullified the force of the enchantment by prayer , and had killed [[my]0-i thirteen knights]644-my thirteen knights in a three hours ' battle , and taken [me]0-i prisoner , sparing [my]0-i life in order that so strange a curiosity as [I]0-i was might be exhibited to the wonder and admiration of [the king]4445-the king and [the court]550-the court . [He]123-sir kay spoke of [me]0-i all the time , in the blandest way , as “ [this prodigious giant]4507-this prodigious giant , ”[123-sir kay] and “ this horrible sky - towering monster , ”[123-sir kay] and “ [this tusked and taloned man - devouring ogre ”]4508-this tusked and taloned man - devouring ogre ”[123-sir kay] , and [everybody]600-everybody took in all this bosh in the naivest way , and never smiled or seemed to notice that there was any discrepancy between [these watered statistics]648-these watered statistics and [me]0-i . [He]123-sir kay said that in trying to escape from [him]123-sir kay [I]0-i sprang into the top of a tree two hundred cubits high at a single bound , but [he]123-sir kay dislodged [me]0-i with a stone the size of a cow , which “ all - to brast ”[123-sir kay] the most of [my]0-i bones , and then swore [me]0-i to appear at [[Arthur]137-arthur 's court]595-arthur 's court for sentence . [He]123-sir kay ended by condemning [me]0-i to die at noon on the 21st ; and was so little concerned about it that [he]123-sir kay stopped to yawn before [he]123-sir kay named the date . [I]0-i was in a dismal state by this time ; indeed , [I]0-i was hardly enough in [my]0-i right mind to keep the run of a dispute that sprung up as to how [I]0-i had better be killed , the possibility of the killing being doubted by [some]617-some , because of the enchantment in [my]0-i clothes . And yet it was nothing but an ordinary suit of fifteen - dollar slop - shops . Still , [I]0-i was sane enough to notice this detail , to wit : many of the terms used in the most matter - of - fact way by [this great assemblage of [the first ladies]652-the first ladies and gentlemen in [the land]4486-the land]651-this great assemblage of the first ladies and gentlemen in the land would have made [a Comanche]654-a comanche blush . Indelicacy is too mild a term to convey the idea . However , [I]0-i had read “ [Tom Jones]141-jones , ”[654-a comanche] and “ Roderick Random , ”[654-a comanche] and other books of that kind , and knew that [the highest and first ladies]655-the highest and first ladies and gentlemen in [England]1-england had remained little or no cleaner in [their]655-the highest and first ladies talk , and in the morals and conduct which such talk implies , clear up to a hundred years ago ; in fact clear into [our]656-our own nineteenth century -- in which century , broadly speaking , the earliest samples of [the real lady]657-the real lady and [real gentleman discoverable in English history]658-real gentleman discoverable in english history -- or in European history , for that matter -- may be said to have made [their]655-the highest and first ladies appearance . Suppose [Sir Walter]142-sir walter , instead of putting the conversations into the mouths of [[his]142-sir walter characters]659-his characters , had allowed [the characters]660-the characters to speak for [themselves]660-the characters ? [We]656-our should have had talk from [Rebecca]143-rebecca and [Ivanhoe]144-ivanhoe and [the soft lady [Rowena]145-rowena]661-the soft lady rowena which would embarrass [a tramp]662-a tramp in [our]656-our day . However , to the unconsciously indelicate all things are delicate . [[King Arthur]116-arthur 's people]663-king arthur 's people were not aware that [they]663-king arthur 's people were indecent and [I]0-i had presence of mind enough not to mention it . [They]663-king arthur 's people were so troubled about [my]0-i enchanted clothes that [they]663-king arthur 's people were mightily relieved , at last , when [old Merlin]134-merlin swept the difficulty away for [them]663-king arthur 's people with a common - sense hint . [He]134-merlin asked [them]663-king arthur 's people why [they]663-king arthur 's people were so dull -- why did n't it occur to [them]663-king arthur 's people to strip [me]0-i . In half a minute [I]0-i was as naked as a pair of tongs ! And dear , [dear]664-dear , to think of it : [I]0-i was [the only embarrassed person there]665-the only embarrassed person there . [Everybody]600-everybody discussed [me]0-i ; and did it as unconcernedly as if [I]0-i had been [a cabbage]667-a cabbage . [Queen Guenever]124-guenever was as naively interested as the rest , and said [she]124-guenever had never seen [anybody]553-anybody with legs just like [mine]0-i before . It was the only compliment [I]0-i got -- if it was a compliment . Finally [I]0-i was carried off in one direction , and [my]0-i perilous clothes in another . [I]0-i was shoved into [a dark and narrow cell in [a dungeon]521-a dungeon]669-a dark and narrow cell in a dungeon , with some scant remnants for dinner , some moldy straw for a bed , and no end of rats for company . CHAPTER V AN INSPIRATION [I]0-i was so tired that even [my]0-i fears were not able to keep [me]0-i awake long . When [I]0-i next came to [myself]0-i , [I]0-i seemed to have been asleep a very long time . [My]0-i first thought was , “ Well , what an astonishing dream [I]0-i 've had ! [I]0-i reckon [I]0-i 've waked only just in time to keep from being hanged or drowned or burned or something .... [I]0-i 'll nap again till the whistle blows , and then [I]0-i 'll go down to [the arms factory]4509-the arms factory and have it out with [Hercules]125-hercules . ”[0-i] But just then [I]0-i heard the harsh music of rusty chains and bolts , a light flashed in [my]0-i eyes , and that butterfly , [Clarence]131-clarence , stood before [me]0-i ! [I]0-i gasped with surprise ; [my]0-i breath almost got away from [me]0-i . “ What ! ”[0-i] [I]0-i said , “ [you]131-clarence here yet ? Go along with the rest of the dream ! scatter ! ”[0-i] But [he]131-clarence only laughed , in [his]131-clarence light - hearted way , and fell to making fun of [my]0-i sorry plight . “ All right , ”[0-i] [I]0-i said resignedly , “ let the dream go on ; [I]0-i 'm in no hurry . ”[0-i] “ Prithee what dream ? ”[131-clarence] “ What dream ? Why , the dream that [I]0-i am in [[Arthur]116-arthur 's court]595-arthur 's court -- [a person who never existed]4511-a person who never existed ; and that [I]0-i am talking to [you]131-clarence , who are nothing but a work of the imagination . ”[0-i] “ Oh , la , indeed ! and is it a dream that [you]131-clarence 're to be burned to - morrow ? Ho - ho -- answer [me]0-i that ! ”[0-i] The shock that went through [me]0-i was distressing . [I]0-i now began to reason that [my]0-i situation was in the last degree serious , dream or no dream ; for [I]0-i knew by past experience of the lifelike intensity of dreams , that to be burned to death , even in a dream , would be very far from being a jest , and was a thing to be avoided , by any means , fair or foul , that [I]0-i could contrive . So [I]0-i said beseechingly : “ Ah , [Clarence]131-clarence , [good boy]4512-good boy , [only friend]4513-only friend [I]0-i 've got,--for [you]131-clarence _ are _ [[my]0-i friend]4514-my friend , are n't you?--don't fail [me]0-i ; help [me]0-i to devise some way of escaping from [this place]4515-this place ! ”[0-i] “ Now do but hear [thyself]4516-thyself ! Escape ? Why , [man]4450-man , [the corridors]4518-the corridors are in guard and keep of [men - at - arms]497-men - at - arms . ”[671-i] “ No doubt , no doubt . But how many , [Clarence]131-clarence ? Not many , [I]671-i hope ? ”[671-i] “ Full a score . [One]434-one may not hope to escape . ”[0-i] After a pause --hesitatingly : “ and there be other reasons -- and weightier . ”[0-i] “ Other ones ? What are [they]4521-they ? ”[671-i] “ Well , [they]4521-they say -- oh , but [I]671-i dare n't , indeed dare n't ! ”[671-i] “ Why , [poor lad]4522-poor lad , what is the matter ? Why do [you]4522-poor lad blench ? Why do [you]4522-poor lad tremble so ? ”[671-i] “ Oh , in sooth , there is need ! [I]671-i do want to tell [you]4522-poor lad , but-- ”[671-i] “ Come , come , be brave , be [a man]518-a man -- speak out , there 's [a good lad]4524-a good lad ! ”[671-i] [He]671-i hesitated , pulled one way by desire , the other way by fear ; then [he]671-i stole to the door and peeped out , listening ; and finally crept close to [me]0-i and put [his]671-i mouth to [my]0-i ear and told [me]0-i [his]671-i fearful news in a whisper , and with all the cowering apprehension of [one who was venturing upon awful ground and speaking of things whose very mention might be freighted with death]672-one who was venturing upon awful ground and speaking of things whose very mention might be freighted with death . “ [Merlin]134-merlin , in [his]134-merlin malice , has woven a spell about [this dungeon]4525-this dungeon , and there bides not [the man in [these kingdoms]4527-these kingdoms that would be desperate enough to essay to cross [its]4525-this dungeon lines with [you]0-i]4526-the man in these kingdoms that would be desperate enough to essay to cross its lines with you ! Now [God]121-god pity [me]0-i , [I]0-i have told it ! Ah , be kind to [me]0-i , be merciful to [a poor boy who means [thee]0-i well]4528-a poor boy who means thee well ; for an [thou]0-i betray [me]0-i [I]0-i am lost ! ”[0-i] [I]0-i laughed the only really refreshing laugh [I]0-i had had for some time ; and shouted : “ [Merlin]134-merlin has wrought a spell ! _ [Merlin]134-merlin _ , forsooth ! [That cheap old humbug]4529-that cheap old humbug , [that maundering old ass]4530-that maundering old ass ? [Bosh]146-bosh , pure bosh , [the silliest bosh in [the world]374-the world]4531-the silliest bosh in the world ! Why , it does seem to [me]0-i that of all the childish , idiotic , chuckle - headed , chicken - livered superstitions that ev --oh , damn [Merlin]134-merlin ! ”[0-i] But [Clarence]131-clarence had slumped to [his]131-clarence knees before [I]0-i had half finished , and [he]131-clarence was like to go out of [his]131-clarence mind with fright . “ Oh , beware ! These are awful words ! Any moment these walls may crumble upon [us]4533-us if [you]131-clarence say such things . Oh call them back before it is too late ! ”[131-clarence] Now this strange exhibition gave [me]0-i a good idea and set [me]0-i to thinking . If [everybody about here]673-everybody about here was so honestly and sincerely afraid of [Merlin]134-merlin 's pretended magic as [Clarence]131-clarence was , certainly [a superior man like [me]0-i]674-a superior man like me ought to be shrewd enough to contrive some way to take advantage of such a state of things . [I]0-i went on thinking , and worked out a plan . Then [I]0-i said : “ Get up . Pull [yourself]131-clarence together ; look [me]0-i in the eye . Do [you]131-clarence know why [I]0-i laughed ? ”[0-i] “ No -- but for [[our]4533-us blessed Lady]4534-our blessed lady 's sake , do it no more . ”[0-i] “ Well , [I]0-i 'll tell [you]131-clarence why [I]0-i laughed . Because [I]0-i 'm [a magician]4535-a magician [myself]0-i . ”[0-i] “ [Thou]4536-thou ! ”[506-the boy] [The boy]506-the boy recoiled a step , and caught [his]506-the boy breath , for the thing hit [him]506-the boy rather sudden ; but the aspect which [he]506-the boy took on was very , very respectful . [I]0-i took quick note of that ; it indicated that [a humbug]676-a humbug did n't need to have a reputation in [this asylum]677-this asylum ; [people]357-people stood ready to take [him]506-the boy at [his]506-the boy word , without that . [I]0-i resumed . “ [I]0-i 've known [Merlin]134-merlin seven hundred years , and [he--]134-merlin ”[0-i] “ Seven hun-- ”[0-i] “ Do n't interrupt [me]679-the poor boy . [He]134-merlin has died and come alive again thirteen times , and traveled under a new name every time : [Smith]147-smith , [Jones]141-jones , [Robinson]148-robinson , [Jackson]149-jackson , [Peters]150-peters , [Haskins]151-haskins , [Merlin]134-merlin -- a new alias every time [he]134-merlin turns up . [He]134-merlin do n't amount to shucks , as [a magician]4535-a magician ; knows some of the old common tricks , but has never got beyond the rudiments , and never will . [He]134-merlin is well enough for [the provinces]4538-the provinces -- one - night stands and that sort of thing , [you]4539-you know -- but dear [me]679-the poor boy , _ [he]134-merlin _ ought n't to set up for [an expert]4540-an expert -- anyway not where there 's [a real artist]4541-a real artist . [I]679-the poor boy want [you]131-clarence to do [me]679-the poor boy a favor . Will [you]131-clarence get that to [the king]4445-the king for [me]679-the poor boy ? ”[679-the poor boy] [The poor boy]679-the poor boy was in such a state that [he]679-the poor boy could hardly answer [me]0-i . It was pitiful to see a creature so terrified , so unnerved , so demoralized . But [he]679-the poor boy promised everything ; and on [my]0-i side [he]679-the poor boy made [me]0-i promise over and over again that [I]0-i would remain [[his]679-the poor boy friend]680-his friend , and never turn against [him]679-the poor boy or cast any enchantments upon [him]679-the poor boy . Then [he]679-the poor boy worked [his]679-the poor boy way out , staying [himself]679-the poor boy with [his]679-the poor boy hand along the wall , like [a sick person]681-a sick person . Presently this thought occurred to [me]0-i : how heedless [I]0-i have been ! When [the boy]506-the boy gets calm , [he]506-the boy will wonder why [a great magician like [me]0-i]683-a great magician like me should have begged [a boy like [him]506-the boy]684-a boy like him to help [me]0-i get out of [this place]4515-this place ; [he]506-the boy will put this and that together , and will see that [I]0-i am [a humbug]676-a humbug . [I]0-i was at rest , then . But as soon as one is at rest , in [this world]352-this world , off [he]689-he goes on something else to worry about . It occurred to [me]0-i that [I]0-i had made another blunder : [I]0-i had sent [the boy]506-the boy off to alarm [[his]506-the boy betters]691-his betters with a threat -- [I]0-i intending to invent a calamity at [my]0-i leisure ; now [the people who are the readiest and eagerest and willingest to swallow miracles]692-the people who are the readiest and eagerest and willingest to swallow miracles are [the very ones who are hungriest to see [you]694-i perform them]693-the very ones who are hungriest to see you perform them ; suppose [I]0-i should be called on for a sample ?
