Year and day -- and without baggage . It was of a piece with the general simplicity of [the country]420-the country . The sun was now setting . It was about three in the afternoon when [Alisande]195-alisande had begun to tell [me]0-i who [the cowboys]4684-the cowboys were ; so [she]195-alisande had made pretty good progress with it -- for [her]195-alisande . [She]195-alisande would arrive some time or other , no doubt , but [she]195-alisande was not [a person who could be hurried]1619-a person who could be hurried . [We]1620-we were approaching [a castle which stood on high ground]1621-a castle which stood on high ground ; [a huge , strong , venerable structure , whose gray towers and battlements were charmingly draped with ivy]1622-a huge , strong , venerable structure , whose gray towers and battlements were charmingly draped with ivy , and whose whole majestic mass was drenched with splendors flung from the sinking sun . [It]1621-a castle which stood on high ground was [the largest castle [we]1620-we had seen]1623-the largest castle we had seen , and so [I]0-i thought it might be [the one [we]1620-we were after]1624-the one we were after , but [Sandy]199-sandy said no . [She]199-sandy did not know who owned [it]1621-a castle which stood on high ground ; [she]199-sandy said [she]199-sandy had passed it without calling , when [she]199-sandy went down to [Camelot]7-camelot . CHAPTER XVI MORGAN LE FAY If [knights errant]1625-knights errant were to be believed , not [all castles]1626-all castles were [desirable places to seek hospitality in]1627-desirable places to seek hospitality in . As a matter of fact , [knights errant]1625-knights errant were _ not _ [persons to be believed]1629-persons to be believed -- that is , measured by modern standards of veracity ; yet , measured by the standards of [their]1625-knights errant own time , and scaled accordingly , [you]1630-you got the truth . It was very simple : [you]1630-you discounted a statement ninety - seven per cent ; the rest was fact . Now after making this allowance , the truth remained that if [I]0-i could find out something about [a castle]4622-a castle before ringing the door - bell -- [I]0-i mean hailing [the warders]1632-the warders -- it was the sensible thing to do . So [I]0-i was pleased when [I]0-i saw in the distance [a horseman making the bottom turn of [the road]460-the road that wound down from [this castle]4604-this castle]1633-a horseman making the bottom turn of the road that wound down from this castle . As [we]1636-we approached [each other]1058-each other , [I]0-i saw that [he]1633-a horseman making the bottom turn of the road that wound down from this castle wore a plumed helmet , and seemed to be otherwise clothed in steel , but bore a curious addition also -- a stiff square garment like [a herald]1638-a herald 's tabard . However , [I]0-i had to smile at [my]0-i own forgetfulness when [I]0-i got nearer and read this sign on [his]1633-a horseman making the bottom turn of the road that wound down from this castle tabard : _ “ [Persimmon]214-persimmon 's Soap -- All the Prime - Donna Use It . ”[0-i] _ That was a little idea of [my]0-i own , and had several wholesome purposes in view toward the civilizing and uplifting of [this nation]1639-this nation . In the first place , it was a furtive , underhand blow at this nonsense of knight errantry , though [nobody]476-nobody suspected that but [me]0-i . [I]0-i had started [a number of [these people]551-these people]1641-a number of these people out -- [the bravest knights [I]0-i could get]1643-the bravest knights i could get -- each sandwiched between bulletin - boards bearing one device or another , and [I]0-i judged that by and by when [they]1641-a number of these people got to be numerous enough [they]1641-a number of these people would begin to look ridiculous ; and then , even the steel - clad ass that _ had n't _ any board would [himself]1633-a horseman making the bottom turn of the road that wound down from this castle begin to look ridiculous because [he]1633-a horseman making the bottom turn of the road that wound down from this castle was out of the fashion . Secondly , [these missionaries]1644-these missionaries would gradually , and without creating suspicion or exciting alarm , introduce a rudimentary cleanliness among [the nobility]1645-the nobility , and from [them]1644-these missionaries it would work down to [the people]753-the people , if [the priests]1232-the priests could be kept quiet . This would undermine [the Church]18-the church . [I]0-i mean would be a step toward that . Next , education -- next , freedom --and then [she]1648-she would begin to crumble . It being [my]0-i conviction that [any Established Church]1649-any established church is an established crime , an established slave - pen , [I]0-i had no scruples , but was willing to assail it in any way or with any weapon that promised to hurt it . Why , in [my]0-i own former day -- in remote centuries not yet stirring in the womb of time -- there were [old Englishmen who imagined that [they]1650-old englishmen who imagined that they had been born in a free country had been born in [a free country]1651-a free country]1650-old englishmen who imagined that they had been born in a free country : [a “ free ”[1650-old englishmen who imagined that they had been born in a free country] country]1652-a “ free ” country with the Corporation Act and the Test still in force in it -- timbers propped against [men]508-men 's liberties and dishonored consciences to shore up an Established Anachronism with . [[My]0-i missionaries]1654-my missionaries were taught to spell out the gilt signs on [their]1654-my missionaries tabards -- the showy gilding was a neat idea , [I]0-i could have got [the king]4445-the king to wear a bulletin - board for the sake of that barbaric splendor -- [they]1654-my missionaries were to spell out these signs and then explain to [the lords]1656-the lords and [ladies]1049-ladies what soap was ; and if [the lords]1656-the lords and [ladies]1049-ladies were afraid of it , get [them]1654-my missionaries to try it on a dog . [The missionary]1660-the missionary 's next move was to get [the family]1661-the family together and try it on [himself]1660-the missionary ; [he]1660-the missionary was to stop at no experiment , however desperate , that could convince [the nobility]1645-the nobility that soap was harmless ; if any final doubt remained , [he]1660-the missionary must catch [a hermit]1663-a hermit -- [the woods]4638-the woods were full of [them]1663-a hermit ; [saints]1665-saints [they]1663-a hermit called [themselves]1663-a hermit , and [saints]1665-saints [they]1663-a hermit were believed to be . [They]1663-a hermit were unspeakably holy , and worked miracles , and [everybody]600-everybody stood in awe of [them]1663-a hermit . As a consequence [the workers in [the field]1674-the field]1673-the workers in the field were increasing by degrees , and the reform was steadily spreading . [[My]0-i soap factory]1675-my soap factory felt the strain early . At first [I]0-i had only two hands ; but before [I]0-i had left [home]619-home [I]0-i was already employing fifteen , and running night and day ; and the atmospheric result was getting so pronounced that [the king]4445-the king went sort of fainting and gasping around and said [he]4445-the king did not believe [he]4445-the king could stand it much longer , and [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot got so that [he]122-sir launcelot did hardly anything but walk up and down the roof and swear , although [I]0-i told [him]122-sir launcelot it was worse up there than anywhere else , but [he]122-sir launcelot said [he]122-sir launcelot wanted plenty of air ; and [he]122-sir launcelot was always complaining that [a palace]1678-a palace was no place for [a soap factory]1679-a soap factory anyway , and said if [a man]518-a man was to start one in [[his]518-a man house]1681-his house [he]518-a man would be damned if [he]518-a man would n't strangle [him]518-a man . [This missionary knight]1686-this missionary knight 's name was [La Cote Male Taile]183-la cote male taile , and [he]1686-this missionary knight said that [this castle]4604-this castle was [the abode of [Morgan le Fay]215-morgan le fay]1688-the abode of morgan le fay , [sister of [King Arthur]1690-king arthur]1689-sister of king arthur , and wife of [King Uriens]188-king uriens , monarch of [a realm about as big as [the District of]1692-the district of [Columbia]36-columbia]1691-a realm about as big as the district of columbia -- [you]1693-you could stand in the middle of [it]4604-this castle and throw bricks into [the next kingdom]1694-the next kingdom . “ [Kings ”]4815-kings ”[183-la cote male taile] and “ Kingdoms ”[183-la cote male taile] were as thick in [Britain]32-britain as they had been in little [Palestine]37-palestine in [Joshua]216-joshua 's time , when [people]357-people had to sleep with [their]357-people knees pulled up because [they]357-people could n't stretch out without a passport . [She]217-mrs. le fay was held in awe by [the whole realm]1714-the whole realm , for [she]217-mrs. le fay had made [everybody]600-everybody believe [she]217-mrs. le fay was [a great sorceress]1716-a great sorceress . [I]0-i was most curious to see [her]217-mrs. le fay ; as curious as [I]0-i could have been to see [Satan]218-satan . [She]1726-this woman clouded up like storm ; [she]1726-this woman called for [[her]1726-this woman guards]1745-her guards , and said : “ Hale [me]1726-this woman these varlets to [the dungeons]4821-the dungeons . ”[1726-this woman] That struck cold on [my]0-i ears , for [[her]1726-this woman dungeons]1746-her dungeons had a reputation . As [the guard]1747-the guard laid a hand upon [me]0-i , [she]1726-this woman piped up with the tranquilest confidence , and said : “ [God]121-god 's wounds , dost [thou]0-i covet destruction , [thou]0-i maniac ? It is [The Boss]1014-the boss ! ”[1726-this woman] Now what a happy idea that was!--and so simple ; yet it would never have occurred to [me]0-i . [I]0-i was born modest ; not all over , but in spots ; and this was one of the spots . The effect upon [madame]1734-madame was electrical . It cleared [her]1734-madame countenance and brought back [her]1734-madame smiles and all [her]1734-madame persuasive graces and blandishments ; but nevertheless [she]1734-madame was not able to entirely cover up with [them]1749-them the fact that [she]1734-madame was in a ghastly fright . CHAPTER XVII [A ROYAL BANQUET Madame]1751-a royal banquet madame , seeing [me]0-i pacific and unresentful , no doubt judged that [I]0-i was deceived by [her]1751-a royal banquet madame excuse ; for [her]1751-a royal banquet madame fright dissolved away , and [she]1751-a royal banquet madame was soon so importunate to have [me]0-i give an exhibition and kill [somebody]1383-somebody , that the thing grew to be embarrassing . However , to [my]0-i relief [she]1751-a royal banquet madame was presently interrupted by the call to prayers . [I]0-i will say this much for [the nobility]1645-the nobility : that , tyrannical , murderous , rapacious , and morally rotten as [they]1645-the nobility were , [they]1645-the nobility were deeply and enthusiastically religious . Nothing could divert [them]1645-the nobility from the regular and faithful performance of the pieties enjoined by [the Church]900-the church . More than once [I]0-i had seen [a noble who had gotten [[his]1755-a noble who had gotten his enemy at a disadvantage , stop to pray before cutting his throat ; more than once i had seen a noble , after ambushing and despatching his enemy enemy]1756-his enemy at a disadvantage , stop to pray before cutting [his]1755-a noble who had gotten his enemy at a disadvantage , stop to pray before cutting his throat ; more than once i had seen a noble , after ambushing and despatching his enemy throat ; more than once [I]0-i had seen [a noble]1128-a noble , after ambushing and despatching [[his]1128-a noble enemy]1756-his enemy]1755-a noble who had gotten his enemy at a disadvantage , stop to pray before cutting his throat ; more than once i had seen a noble , after ambushing and despatching his enemy , retire to [the nearest wayside shrine]1759-the nearest wayside shrine and humbly give thanks , without even waiting to rob the body . There was to be nothing finer or sweeter in the life of even [Benvenuto Cellini]220-benvenuto cellini , [that rough - hewn saint]1760-that rough - hewn saint , ten centuries later . [All the nobles of [Britain]32-britain]1761-all the nobles of britain , with [[their]1761-all the nobles of britain families]479-their families , attended divine service morning and night daily , in [[their]1761-all the nobles of britain private chapels]1763-their private chapels , and [even the worst of [them]1761-all the nobles of britain]1764-even the worst of them had [family]1765-family worship five or six times a day besides . The credit of this belonged entirely to [the Church]900-the church . Although [I]0-i was [no friend to [that Catholic Church]1768-that catholic church]1767-no friend to that catholic church , [I]0-i was obliged to admit this . And often , in spite of [me]0-i , [I]0-i found [myself]0-i saying , “ What would [this country]4644-this country be without [the Church]900-the church ? ”[0-i] After prayers [we]1769-we had dinner in [a great banqueting hall]1770-a great banqueting hall which was lighted by hundreds of grease - jets , and everything was as fine and lavish and rudely splendid as might become the royal degree of [the hosts]1771-the hosts . At the head of [the hall]364-the hall , on a dais , was the table of [the king]4445-the king , [queen]1774-queen , and [[their]1775-their son]1776-their son , [Prince Uwaine]221-prince uwaine . Stretching down [the hall]364-the hall from this , was the general table , on the floor . At this , above the salt , sat [the visiting nobles]1778-the visiting nobles and [the grown members of [[their]1778-the visiting nobles families]479-their families , of both sexes,--the resident Court , in effect -- [sixty - one persons]1781-sixty - one persons]1779-the grown members of their families , of both sexes,--the resident court , in effect -- sixty - one persons ; below the salt sat [minor officers of [the household]1783-the household]1782-minor officers of the household , with [[their]1782-minor officers of the household principal subordinates]1784-their principal subordinates : altogether [a hundred and eighteen persons sitting , and about as many liveried servants]1785-a hundred and eighteen persons sitting , and about as many liveried servants standing behind [their]1785-a hundred and eighteen persons sitting , and about as many liveried servants chairs , or serving in one capacity or another . It was a very fine show . In [a gallery]1786-a gallery [a band with cymbals , horns , harps , and other horrors]1787-a band with cymbals , horns , harps , and other horrors , opened the proceedings with what seemed to be the crude first - draft or original agony of the wail known to later centuries as “ In the Sweet Bye and Bye . ”[579-the queen] It was new , and ought to have been rehearsed a little more . For some reason or other [the queen]579-the queen had [the composer]1789-the composer hanged , after dinner . After this music , [the priest who stood behind the royal table]1790-the priest who stood behind the royal table said a noble long grace in ostensible Latin . Then [the battalion of [waiters]1792-waiters]1791-the battalion of waiters broke away from [their]1791-the battalion of waiters posts , and darted , rushed , flew , fetched and carried , and the mighty feeding began ; no words anywhere , but absorbing attention to business . The rows of chops opened and shut in vast unison , and the sound of it was like to the muffled burr of subterranean machinery . The havoc continued an hour and a half , and unimaginable was the destruction of substantials . Of the chief feature of the feast --the huge wild boar that lay stretched out so portly and imposing at the start -- nothing was left but the semblance of a hoop - skirt ; and [he]1793-he was but the type and symbol of what had happened to all the other dishes . With the pastries and so on , the heavy drinking began -- and the talk . Gallon after gallon of wine and mead disappeared , and [everybody]600-everybody got comfortable , then happy , then sparklingly joyous -- [both sexes]1795-both sexes , --and by and by pretty noisy . [Men]508-men told anecdotes that were terrific to hear , but [nobody]476-nobody blushed ; and when the nub was sprung , [the assemblage]738-the assemblage let go with a horse - laugh that shook [the fortress]1799-the fortress . [Ladies]1049-ladies answered back with historiettes that would almost have made [Queen Margaret of Navarre]222-queen margaret of navarre or even [the great Elizabeth of [England]1-england]1801-the great elizabeth of england hide behind a handkerchief , but [nobody]476-nobody hid [here]369-here , but only laughed --howled , [you]1804-you may say . In pretty much all of these dreadful stories , [ecclesiastics]1805-ecclesiastics were [the hardy heroes]1806-the hardy heroes , but that did n't worry [the chaplain]1807-the chaplain any , [he]1807-the chaplain had [his]1807-the chaplain laugh with the rest ; more than that , upon invitation [he]1807-the chaplain roared out a song which was of as daring a sort as any that was sung that night . By midnight [everybody]600-everybody was fagged out , and sore with laughing ; and , as a rule , [drunk]1809-drunk : [some weepingly]1810-some weepingly , some affectionately , some hilariously , some quarrelsomely , some dead and under the table . Of [the ladies]545-the ladies , the worst spectacle was [a lovely young duchess]1812-a lovely young duchess , whose wedding - eve this was ; and indeed [she]1812-a lovely young duchess was a spectacle , sure enough . Just as [she]1812-a lovely young duchess was [she]1812-a lovely young duchess could have sat in advance for the portrait of [the young daughter of [the Regent d'Orleans]1814-the regent d'orleans]1813-the young daughter of the regent d'orleans , at the famous dinner whence [she]1812-a lovely young duchess was carried , foul - mouthed , intoxicated , and helpless , to [her]1812-a lovely young duchess bed , in the lost and lamented days of [the Ancient Regime]1815-the ancient regime . Well , well , well , [they]1833-they _ were _ [a superstitious lot]1834-a superstitious lot . It is all a body can do to conceive of it . [The poor queen]1835-the poor queen was so scared and humbled that [she]1835-the poor queen was even afraid to hang [the composer]1789-the composer without first consulting [me]0-i . [I]0-i was very sorry for [her]1835-the poor queen -- indeed , [any one]1127-any one would have been , for [she]1835-the poor queen was really suffering ; so [I]0-i was willing to do anything that was reasonable , and had no desire to carry things to wanton extremities . [I]0-i therefore considered the matter thoughtfully , and ended by having [the musicians]546-the musicians ordered into [our]1839-our presence to play that Sweet Bye and Bye again , which [they]546-the musicians did . Then [I]0-i saw that [she]1835-the poor queen was right , and gave [her]1835-the poor queen permission to hang [the whole band]1840-the whole band . This little relaxation of sternness had a good effect upon [the queen]579-the queen . [A statesman]1034-a statesman gains little by the arbitrary exercise of iron - clad authority upon all occasions that offer , for this wounds the just pride of [[his]1034-a statesman subordinates]1843-his subordinates , and thus tends to undermine [his]1034-a statesman strength . [I]0-i had a great desire to rack [the executioner]1866-the executioner ; not because [he]536-the man was [a good , painstaking and paingiving official,--for]1907-a good , painstaking and paingiving official,--for surely it was not to [his]536-the man discredit that [he]536-the man performed [his]536-the man functions well -- but to pay [him]536-the man back for wantonly cuffing and otherwise distressing [that young woman]1908-that young woman . [The priests]1232-the priests told [me]0-i about this , and were generously hot to have [him]536-the man punished . Something of this disagreeable sort was turning up every now and then . [I]0-i mean , episodes that showed that [not all priests]1910-not all priests were [frauds and self - seekers]1911-frauds and self - seekers , but that many , even [the great majority , of these that were down on the ground among [the common people]1913-the common people]1912-the great majority , of these that were down on the ground among the common people , were sincere and right - hearted , and devoted to the alleviation of human troubles and sufferings . Well , it was a thing which could not be helped , so [I]0-i seldom fretted about it , and never many minutes at a time ; it has never been [my]0-i way to bother much about things which [you]1914-you ca n't cure . But [I]0-i did not like it , for it was just the sort of thing to keep [people]357-people reconciled to [an Established Church]1510-an established church . [We]1917-we _ must _ have a religion --it goes without saying -- but [my]0-i idea is , to have it cut up into forty free sects , so that [they]1232-the priests will police [each other]1058-each other , as had been the case in [the United States]38-the united states in [my]0-i time . Concentration of power in a political machine is bad ; and [an Established Church]1510-an established church is only a political machine ; it was invented for that ; it is nursed , cradled , preserved for that ; it is an enemy to human liberty , and does no good which [it]1510-an established church could not better do in a split - up and scattered condition . That was n't law ; it was n't gospel : it was only an opinion -- [my]0-i opinion , and [I]0-i was only [a man]518-a man , [one man]543-one man : so it was n't worth any more than [the pope's]1922-the pope's -- or any less , for that matter . Well , [I]0-i could n't rack [the executioner]1866-the executioner , neither would [I]0-i overlook the just complaint of [the priests]1232-the priests . [The man]536-the man must be punished somehow or other , so [I]0-i degraded [him]536-the man from [[his]536-the man office]1926-his office and made [him]536-the man [leader of [the band]1928-the band]1927-leader of the band -- the new one that was to be started . [He]536-the man begged hard , and said [he]536-the man could n't play -- a plausible excuse , but too thin ; there was n't [a musician in [the country]420-the country]1929-a musician in the country that could . [The queen]579-the queen was a good deal outraged , next morning when [she]579-the queen found [she]579-the queen was going to have neither [Hugo]225-hugo 's life nor [his]225-hugo property . But [I]0-i told [her]579-the queen [she]579-the queen must bear this cross ; that while by law and custom [she]579-the queen certainly was entitled to both [the man]536-the man 's life and [his]225-hugo property , there were extenuating circumstances , and so in [Arthur]116-arthur [the king]4445-the king 's name [I]0-i had pardoned [him]536-the man . The deer was ravaging [[the man]536-the man 's fields]1935-the man 's fields , and [he]536-the man had killed it in sudden passion , and not for gain ; and [he]536-the man had carried it into [the royal forest]1936-the royal forest in the hope that that might make detection of [the misdoer]1937-the misdoer impossible . Confound [her]579-the queen , [I]0-i could n't make [her]579-the queen see that sudden passion is an extenuating circumstance in the killing of venison -- or of [a person]966-a person -- so [I]0-i gave it up and let [her]579-the queen sulk it out . [I]0-i _ did _ think [I]0-i was going to make [her]579-the queen see it by remarking that [her]579-the queen own sudden passion in the case of the page modified that crime . “ Crime ! ”[579-the queen] [she]579-the queen exclaimed . “ How [thou]4901-thou talkest ! Crime , forsooth ! [Man]4450-man , [I]579-the queen am going to _ pay _ for [him]4450-man ! ”[579-the queen] Oh , it was no use to waste sense on [her]579-the queen . Training -- training is everything ; training is all there is _ to _ [a person]966-a person . [We]1940-we speak of nature ; it is folly ; there is no such thing as nature ; what [we]1940-we call by that misleading name is merely heredity and training . [We]1940-we have no thoughts of [our]1940-we own , no opinions of [our]1940-we own ; they are transmitted to [us]1940-we , trained into [us]1940-we . All that is original in [us]1940-we , and therefore fairly creditable or discreditable to [us]1940-we , can be covered up and hidden by the point of a cambric needle , all the rest being atoms contributed by , and inherited from , a procession of [ancestors]1941-ancestors that stretches back a billion years to the Adam - clam or grasshopper or monkey from whom [[our]1940-we race]1942-our race has been so tediously and ostentatiously and unprofitably developed . And as for [me]0-i , all that [I]0-i think about in this plodding sad pilgrimage , this pathetic drift between the eternities , is to look out and humbly live a pure and high and blameless life , and save that one microscopic atom in [me]0-i that is truly _ [me]0-i _ : the rest may land in [Sheol]39-sheol and welcome for all [I]0-i care . No , confound [her]579-the queen , [her]579-the queen intellect was good , [she]579-the queen had brains enough , but [her]579-the queen training made [her]579-the queen an ass -- that is , from a many - centuries - later point of view . To kill the page was no crime -- it was [her]579-the queen right ; and upon [her]579-the queen right [she]579-the queen stood , serenely and unconscious of offense . [She]579-the queen was a result of generations of training in the unexamined and unassailed belief that the law which permitted [her]579-the queen to kill [a subject]1943-a subject when [she]579-the queen chose was a perfectly right and righteous one . Well , [we]1940-we must give even [Satan]218-satan [his]218-satan due . [She]579-the queen deserved a compliment for one thing ; and [I]0-i tried to pay it , but the words stuck in [my]0-i throat . [She]579-the queen had a right to kill [the boy]506-the boy , but [she]579-the queen was in no wise obliged to pay for [him]506-the boy . That was law for [some other people]1945-some other people , but not for [her]579-the queen . [She]579-the queen knew quite well that [she]579-the queen was doing a large and generous thing to pay for [that lad]1946-that lad , and that [I]0-i ought in common fairness to come out with something handsome about it , but [I]0-i couldn't -- [my]0-i mouth refused . [I]0-i could n't help seeing , in [my]0-i fancy , [that poor old grandma with the broken heart]1947-that poor old grandma with the broken heart , and [that fair young creature]1948-that fair young creature lying butchered , [his]506-the boy little silken pomps and vanities laced with [his]506-the boy golden blood . How could [she]579-the queen _ pay _ for [him]506-the boy ! _ Whom _ could [she]579-the queen pay ? And so , well knowing that [this woman]1726-this woman , trained as [she]1726-this woman had been , deserved praise , even adulation , [I]0-i was yet not able to utter it , trained as [I]0-i had been . The best [I]0-i could do was to fish up a compliment from outside , so to speak -- and the pity of it was , that it was true : “ [Madame]1734-madame , [[your]1734-madame people]4904-your people will adore [you]1734-madame for this . ”[0-i] Quite true , but [I]0-i meant to hang [her]1726-this woman for it some day if [I]0-i lived . Some of those laws were too bad , altogether too bad . [A master]1950-a master might kill [[his]1950-a master slave]1951-his slave for nothing -- for mere spite , malice , or to pass the time -- just as [we]1952-we have seen that [the crowned head]1953-the crowned head could do it with _ [[his]1953-the crowned head _ slave]1954-his _ slave , that is to say , [anybody]553-anybody . [A gentleman]1956-a gentleman could kill [a free commoner]1957-a free commoner , and pay for [him]1957-a free commoner -- cash or garden - truck . [A noble]1128-a noble could kill [a noble]1128-a noble without expense , as far as the law was concerned , but reprisals in kind were to be expected . _ [Any_body]1960-any_body could kill _ [some_body]1961-some_body , except [the commoner]969-the commoner and [the slave]1963-the slave ; these had no privileges . If [they]1964-they killed , it was murder , and the law would n't stand murder . It made short work of [the experimenter]1965-the experimenter -- and of [[his]1965-the experimenter family]1966-his family , too , if [he]1965-the experimenter murdered [somebody who belonged up among [the ornamental ranks]1968-the ornamental ranks]1967-somebody who belonged up among the ornamental ranks . [I]0-i had had enough of [this grisly place]1974-this grisly place by this time , and wanted to leave , but [I]0-i could n't , because [I]0-i had something on [my]0-i mind that [my]0-i conscience kept prodding [me]0-i about , and would n't let [me]0-i forget . If [I]0-i had the remaking of [man]4450-man , [he]4450-man would n't have any conscience . It is one of the most disagreeable things connected with [a person]966-a person ; and although it certainly does a great deal of good , it can not be said to pay , in the long run ; it would be much better to have less good and more comfort . Still , this is only [my]0-i opinion , and [I]0-i am [only one man]1977-only one man ; [others]1365-others , with less experience , may think differently . [They]1365-others have a right to [their]1365-others view . [I]0-i only stand to this : [I]0-i have noticed [my]0-i conscience for many years , and [I]0-i know it is more trouble and bother to [me]0-i than anything else [I]0-i started with . [I]0-i suppose that in the beginning [I]0-i prized it , because [we]1979-we prize anything that is [ours]1979-we ; and yet how foolish it was to think so . If [we]1979-we look at it in another way , [we]1979-we see how absurd it is : if [I]0-i had an anvil in [me]0-i would [I]0-i prize it ? Of course not . And yet when [you]1980-you come to think , there is no real difference between a conscience and an anvil -- [I]0-i mean for comfort . [I]0-i have noticed it a thousand times . And [you]1980-you could dissolve an anvil with acids , when [you]1980-you could n't stand it any longer ; but there is n't any way that [you]1980-you can work off a conscience -- at least so it will stay worked off ; not that [I]0-i know of , anyway . There was something [I]0-i wanted to do before leaving , but it was a disagreeable matter , and [I]0-i hated to go at it . Well , it bothered [me]0-i all the morning . [I]0-i wanted to see [the man]536-the man , after hearing all this . [He]536-the man was thirty - four years old , and looked sixty . [They]2112-five whose names , offenses , and dates of incarceration [themselves]2112-five whose names , offenses , and dates of incarceration had long ago forgotten these details ; at any rate [they]2112-five whose names , offenses , and dates of incarceration had mere vague theories about [them]2112-five whose names , offenses , and dates of incarceration , nothing definite and nothing that [they]2112-five whose names , offenses , and dates of incarceration repeated twice in the same way . The succession of [priests whose office it had been to pray]2116-priests whose office it had been to pray daily with [the captives]2117-the captives and remind [them]2117-the captives that [God]121-god had put [them]2117-the captives there , for some wise purpose or other , and teach [them]2117-the captives that patience , humbleness , and submission to oppression was what [He]121-god loved to see in [parties of a subordinate rank]2118-parties of a subordinate rank , had traditions about these poor old human ruins , but nothing more . These traditions went but little way , for they concerned the length of the incarceration only , and not the names of the offenses . And even by the help of tradition the only thing that could be proven was that [none of the five]2119-none of the five had seen daylight for thirty - five years : how much longer this privation has lasted was not guessable . [The king]4445-the king and [the queen]579-the queen knew nothing about these poor creatures , except that [they]2122-them were heirlooms , assets inherited , along with the throne , from [the former firm]2123-the former firm . Nothing of [their]2122-them history had been transmitted with [[their]2122-them persons]2124-their persons , and so [the inheriting owners]2125-the inheriting owners had considered [them]2122-them of no value , and had felt no interest in [them]2122-them . [I]0-i said to [the queen]579-the queen : “ Then why in [the world]374-the world did n't [you]579-the queen set [them]2122-them free ? ”[0-i] The question was a puzzler . [She]579-the queen did n't know _ why _ [she]579-the queen had n't , the thing had never come up in [her]579-the queen mind . So here [she]579-the queen was , forecasting the veritable history of [future prisoners of [the Castle d'If]2128-the castle d'if]2127-future prisoners of the castle d'if , without knowing it . It seemed plain to [me]0-i now , that with [her]579-the queen training , [those inherited prisoners]2129-those inherited prisoners were merely property -- nothing more , nothing less . Well , when [we]2130-we inherit property , it does not occur to [us]2130-we to throw it away , even when [we]2130-we do not value it . When [I]0-i brought [my]0-i procession of human bats up into [the open world]2131-the open world and the glare of the afternoon sun -- previously blindfolding [them]2129-those inherited prisoners , in charity for eyes so long untortured by light -- they were a spectacle to look at . Skeletons , [scarecrows]2132-scarecrows , [goblins]2133-goblins , [pathetic frights]2134-pathetic frights , [every one]1361-every one ; [legitimatest possible children of [Monarchy]230-monarchy by the Grace of [God]121-god]2136-legitimatest possible children of monarchy by the grace of god and [the Established Church]40-the established church . [I]0-i muttered absently : “ [I]0-i _ wish _ [I]0-i could photograph [them]2129-those inherited prisoners ! ”[0-i] [You]2137-you have seen that kind of people who will never let on that [they]2129-those inherited prisoners do n't know the meaning of a new big word . The more ignorant [they]2129-those inherited prisoners are , the more pitifully certain [they]2129-those inherited prisoners are to pretend [you]2137-you have n't shot over [their]2129-those inherited prisoners heads . [The queen]579-the queen was just one of that sort , and was always making the stupidest blunders by reason of it . [She]579-the queen hesitated a moment ; then [her]579-the queen face brightened up with sudden comprehension , and [she]579-the queen said [she]579-the queen would do it for [me]0-i . [I]0-i thought to [myself]0-i : [She]579-the queen ? why what can [she]579-the queen know about photography ? But it was a poor time to be thinking . When [I]0-i looked around , [she]579-the queen was moving on [the procession]1563-the procession with an axe ! Well , [she]579-the queen certainly was [a curious one]2140-a curious one , was [Morgan le Fay]215-morgan le fay . [I]0-i have seen a good many kinds of women in [my]0-i time , but [she]579-the queen laid over [them]2141-them all for variety . And how sharply characteristic of [her]579-the queen this episode was . [She]579-the queen had no more idea than a horse of how to photograph a procession ; but being in doubt , it was just like [her]579-the queen to try to do it with an axe . CHAPTER XIX KNIGHT - ERRANTRY AS A TRADE [Sandy]199-sandy and [I]0-i were on [the road]460-the road again , next morning , bright and early . It was so good to open up [one]434-one 's lungs and take in whole luscious barrels - ful of [the blessed God]2144-the blessed god 's untainted , dew - fashioned , woodland - scented air once more , after suffocating body and mind for two days and nights in the moral and physical stenches of that intolerable old buzzard - roost ! [I]0-i mean , for [me]0-i : of course [the place]448-the place was all right and agreeable enough for [Sandy]199-sandy , for [she]199-sandy had been used to high life all [her]199-sandy days . [Poor girl]2146-poor girl , [her]199-sandy jaws had had a wearisome rest now for a while , and [I]0-i was expecting to get the consequences . [I]0-i was right ; but [she]579-the queen had stood by [me]0-i most helpfully in [the castle]721-the castle , and had mightily supported and reinforced [me]0-i with gigantic foolishnesses which were worth more for the occasion than wisdoms double [their]2148-their size ; so [I]0-i thought [she]579-the queen had earned a right to work [her]579-the queen mill for a while , if [she]579-the queen wanted to , and [I]0-i felt not a pang when [she]579-the queen started it up : “ Now turn [we]4907-they unto [Sir Marhaus]210-sir marhaus that rode with [the damsel of thirty winter of age]4908-the damsel of thirty winter of age southward-- ”[579-the queen] “ Are [you]210-sir marhaus going to see if [you]210-sir marhaus can work up another half - stretch on [the trail of [the cowboys]4684-the cowboys]4909-the trail of the cowboys , [Sandy]199-sandy ? ”[231-the boss] “ Even so , fair [[my]579-the queen lord]1456-my lord . ”[579-the queen] “ Go ahead , then . [I]579-the queen wo n't interrupt this time , if [I]579-the queen can help it . Begin over again ; start fair , and shake out all [your]210-sir marhaus reefs , and [I]579-the queen will load [my]579-the queen pipe and give good attention . ”[579-the queen] “ Now turn [we]4907-they unto [Sir Marhaus]210-sir marhaus that rode with [the damsel of thirty winter of age]4908-the damsel of thirty winter of age southward . And so [they]4907-they came into [a deep forest]4913-a deep forest , and by fortune [they]4907-they were nighted , and rode along in a deep way , and at the last [they]4907-they came into [a courtelage where abode [the duke of [South Marches]41-south marches]4915-the duke of south marches]4914-a courtelage where abode the duke of south marches , and there [they]4907-they asked harbour . And on the morn [the duke]1018-the duke sent unto [Sir Marhaus]210-sir marhaus , and bad [him]210-sir marhaus make [him]210-sir marhaus ready . And so [Sir Marhaus]210-sir marhaus arose and armed [him]210-sir marhaus , and there was a mass sung afore [him]210-sir marhaus , and [he]210-sir marhaus brake [his]210-sir marhaus fast , and so mounted on horseback in [the court of [the castle]721-the castle]4917-the court of the castle , there [they]4907-they should do the battle . So there was [the duke]1018-the duke already on horseback , clean armed , and [[his]1018-the duke six sons]4920-his six sons by [him]1018-the duke , and [every each]4921-every each had a spear in [his]1018-the duke hand , and so [they]4907-they encountered , whereas [the duke]1018-the duke and [[his]1018-the duke two sons]4923-his two sons brake [their]4923-his two sons spears upon [him]1018-the duke , but [Sir Marhaus]210-sir marhaus held up [his]210-sir marhaus spear and touched [none of [them]4923-his two sons]1148-none of them . Then came [the four sons]4925-the four sons by [couples]4926-couples , and two of [them]4925-the four sons brake [their]4923-his two sons spears , and so did [the other two]4927-the other two . And all this while [Sir Marhaus]210-sir marhaus touched [them]4923-his two sons not . Then [Sir Marhaus]210-sir marhaus ran to [the duke]1018-the duke , and smote [him]1018-the duke with [his]210-sir marhaus spear that horse and [man]4450-man fell to [the earth]399-the earth . And so [he]210-sir marhaus served [[his]210-sir marhaus sons]4498-his sons . And then [Sir Marhaus]210-sir marhaus alight down , and bad [the duke]1018-the duke yield [him]210-sir marhaus or else [he]1018-the duke would slay [him]210-sir marhaus . And then [some of [[his]210-sir marhaus sons]4498-his sons]4933-some of his sons recovered , and would have set upon [Sir Marhaus]210-sir marhaus . Then [Sir Marhaus]210-sir marhaus said to [the duke]1018-the duke , Cease [[thy]1018-the duke sons]4936-thy sons , or else [I]231-the boss will do the uttermost to [you]1018-the duke all . Now [ye]231-the boss shall wit that [that very duke]2149-that very duke and [[his]2149-that very duke six sons]4920-his six sons are [they]2151-they whom but few days past [you]231-the boss also did overcome and send to [[Arthur]116-arthur 's court]595-arthur 's court ! ” “[231-the boss] Why , [Sandy]199-sandy , [you]199-sandy ca n't mean it ! ” “[199-sandy] An [I]0-i speak not sooth , let it be the worse for [me]0-i . ” “[0-i] Well , well , well,--now who would ever have thought it ? [One whole duke]2153-one whole duke and [six dukelets]2154-six dukelets ; why , [Sandy]199-sandy , it was an elegant haul . Knight - errantry is a most chuckle - headed trade , and it is tedious hard work , too , but [I]0-i begin to see that there _ is _ money in it , after all , if [you]231-the boss have luck . Not that [I]0-i would ever engage in it as a business , for [I]0-i would n't . No sound and legitimate business can be established on a basis of speculation . A successful whirl in the knight - errantry line -- now what is it when [you]231-the boss blow away the nonsense and come down to the cold facts ? It 's just a corner in pork , that 's all , and [you]231-the boss ca n't make anything else out of it . [You]231-the boss 're rich -- yes,--suddenly rich -- for about a day , maybe a week ; then [somebody]1383-somebody corners [the market]2156-the market on _ [you]231-the boss _ , and down goes [[your]231-the boss bucket - shop]2157-your bucket - shop ; ai n't that so , [Sandy]199-sandy ? ” “[199-sandy] Whethersoever it be that [my]0-i mind miscarrieth , bewraying simple language in such sort that the words do seem to come endlong and overthwart-- ” “[0-i] There 's no use in beating about the bush and trying to get around it that way , [Sandy]199-sandy , it 's _ so _ , just as [I]0-i say . And , moreover , when [you]231-the boss come right down to the bedrock , knight - errantry is _ worse _ than pork ; for whatever happens , the pork 's left , and so [somebody]1383-somebody 's benefited anyway ; but when the market breaks , in a knight - errantry whirl , and [every knight in the pool]2159-every knight in the pool passes in [his]2159-every knight in the pool checks , what have [you]231-the boss got for assets ? Am [I]0-i right ? ” “[0-i] Ah , peradventure [my]0-i head being distraught by the manifold matters whereunto the confusions of these but late adventured haps and fortunings whereby not [I]0-i alone nor [you]231-the boss alone , but [every each of [us]2161-us]2160-every each of us , [meseemeth--]2162-meseemeth-- ” “[2162-meseemeth--] No , it 's not [your]199-sandy head , [Sandy]199-sandy . [Your]199-sandy head 's all right , as far as it goes , but [you]199-sandy do n't know business ; that 's where the trouble is . However , that aside , it was a good haul , anyway , and will breed a handsome crop of reputation in [[Arthur]116-arthur 's court]595-arthur 's court . And speaking of [the cowboys]4684-the cowboys , what [a curious country]902-a curious country this is for [women]532-women and [men that never get old]2167-men that never get old . CHAPTER XX THE OGRE 'S CASTLE Between six and nine [we]4944-we made ten miles , which was plenty for a horse carrying [triple -- man]4945-triple -- man , [woman]4829-woman , and armor ; then [we]4944-we stopped for a long nooning under [some trees]4947-some trees by [a limpid brook]4948-a limpid brook . Right so came by and by [a knight]1057-a knight riding ; and as [he]1057-a knight drew near [he]1057-a knight made dolorous moan , and by the words of it [I]199-sandy perceived that [he]1057-a knight was cursing and swearing ; yet nevertheless was [I]199-sandy glad of [his]1057-a knight coming , for that [I]199-sandy saw [he]1057-a knight bore a bulletin - board whereon in letters all of shining gold was writ : “[199-sandy] USE PETERSON 'S PROPHYLACTIC TOOTH - BRUSH -- ALL THE GO . ” [I]199-sandy was glad of [his]1057-a knight coming , for even by this token [I]199-sandy knew [him]1057-a knight for knight of [mine]199-sandy . It was [Sir Madok de la Montaine]232-sir madok , [a burly great fellow whose chief distinction was that [he]232-sir madok had come within an ace of sending [Sir Launcelot]122-sir launcelot down over [his]232-sir madok horse - tail]4950-a burly great fellow whose chief distinction was that he had come within an ace of sending sir launcelot down over his horse - tail once . [He]232-sir madok was never long in [a stranger]798-a stranger 's presence without finding some pretext or other to let out that great fact . But there was another fact of nearly the same size , which [he]232-sir madok never pushed upon [anybody]553-anybody unasked , and yet never withheld when asked : that was , that the reason [he]232-sir madok did n't quite succeed was , that [he]232-sir madok was interrupted and sent down over horse - tail [himself]232-sir madok . [This innocent vast lubber]4953-this innocent vast lubber did not see any particular difference between the two facts . [I]199-sandy liked [him]1057-a knight , for [he]1057-a knight was earnest in [his]1057-a knight work , and very valuable . And [he]1057-a knight was so fine to look at , with [his]1057-a knight broad mailed shoulders , and the grand leonine set of [his]1057-a knight plumed head , and [his]1057-a knight big shield with its quaint device of a gauntleted hand clutching a prophylactic tooth - brush , with motto : “[199-sandy] Try Noyoudont . ” This was a tooth - wash that [I]2176-him was introducing . [He]232-sir madok was aweary , [he]232-sir madok said , and indeed [he]232-sir madok looked it ; but [he]232-sir madok would not alight . [He]232-sir madok said [he]232-sir madok was after [the stove - polish man]4954-the stove - polish man ; and with this [he]232-sir madok broke out cursing and swearing anew . [The bulletin - boarder]4955-the bulletin - boarder referred to was [Sir Ossaise of Surluse]233-sir ossaise , [a brave knight]4956-a brave knight , and of considerable celebrity on account of [his]233-sir ossaise having tried conclusions in a tournament once , with no less a Mogul than [Sir Gaheris]234-sir gaheris [himself]234-sir gaheris -- although not successfully . [He]233-sir ossaise was of a light and laughing disposition , and to [him]233-sir ossaise nothing in [this world]352-this world was serious . It was for this reason that [I]2176-him had chosen [him]233-sir ossaise to work up a stove - polish sentiment . There were no stoves yet , and so there could be nothing serious about stove - polish . All that [the agent]4958-the agent needed to do was to deftly and by degrees prepare [the public]943-the public for the great change , and have [them]943-the public established in predilections toward neatness against the time when the stove should appear upon the stage . [Sir Madok]232-sir madok was very bitter , and brake out anew with cursings . [He]232-sir madok said [he]232-sir madok had cursed [his]232-sir madok soul to rags ; and yet [he]232-sir madok would not get down from [his]232-sir madok horse , neither would [he]232-sir madok take any rest , or listen to any comfort , until [he]232-sir madok should have found [Sir Ossaise]233-sir ossaise and settled this account . It appeared , by what [I]2176-him could piece together of the unprofane fragments of [his]232-sir madok statement , that [he]232-sir madok had chanced upon [Sir Ossaise]233-sir ossaise at dawn of the morning , and been told that if [he]232-sir madok would make a short cut across [the fields]4960-the fields and [swamps]4961-swamps and broken hills and glades , [he]232-sir madok could head off [a company of travelers who would be rare customers for prophylactics and tooth - wash]4962-a company of travelers who would be rare customers for prophylactics and tooth - wash .
